“None you brought,” Eryn said. “None you rode in with. You have sea words and church words and words for spices traded by men who think a market is a war you can win with a list. None of those will lie properly against this shape. If you wait till it speaks in something like sense, you will earn a syllable. If you jump and plant your clam, we will take it away from you, politely, the way a woman takes glass out of a child’s mouth.”

Tomas took the cleric’s blue stole in two fingers and moved it one inch away from the fringe of the rope where it had been about to trespass. “You pray,” he advised, unnecessarily and exactly. “Not to it. Not for it. In spite of it. To keep your own song steady while this one tries to climb inside your head and conduct.”

Dolores had produced from nowhere a slate and on it she had written three sentences, each in words as short as her patience and twice as durable. No fire. No going past rope. No digging by anyone until a stone-listener says yes. She had a chalk nub that left dust on her fingertips and she wiped the dust on her skirt and the white streaks there were as fair as lace to her. She told a boy to take the slate to the lower crossing and she told a girl to take it to the upper and she told both that if anyone laughed at their size they should invent a new curse and use it twice, once for practice and once for conviction.

The coastal leader looked at Sid with the face of a man who admits to himself that a morning has gone another way than he dreamed it and still intends to sleep well later. “We will not plant a flag,” he said, the words not pleasing him as they came out and therefore proving they were the right ones. “We will stand behind the girl’s rope and we will watch a while. We will send a letter with your man to our city and ask for stones that can listen, if you allow that, and men who do not insult the inlanders’ air by breathing it like the last of something. We will leave our cleric in your keeping so you can see we mean it. He is not a hostage. He is a witness, which is worse if a man knows what a witness can do.”

Sid allowed the least smile. It was the one that said good, I have not had to lie yet, and perhaps today I will sleep in my own bed next to the sound of something not singing. “Leave your cleric if he likes our soup,” he said. “That will mean more to me than your letter. We will share watch and notes. But you will not name things at market. You will not tell men who sell beans that this will bring back the sea. If you do, I will come to your coast and I will sell almonds and call them pearls and I will embarrass you so thoroughly your whalebones will blush.”

The man’s whalebone ring tapped his thigh again as if it had an opinion and was trying to introduce it. He exhaled. “I am Lord Baeza of the Tidemark,” he said, as if giving his name was a concession and an admission and an offering. “If your soup is brined like the last time I ate in this valley, I will insult you in return by teaching your cook to use salt with grace.”

“Soup is already boiling in the upper shade,” Bee reported over her shoulder, as if this had been the plan all month. “Split peas and a ham joint and a handful of that green that grows where it shouldn’t. Two onions. No sermons in the salt. If you don’t like it there is bread. If you don’t like the bread you can go chew your banner.”

Marta had set three cauldrons on stones and announced the law of the soup as if it had been handed down to Moses in the dust: a ladle is a ruler and you do not let any man measure himself longer than anyone else with it. Ajit had wheedled two goatskins of extra water from the upper pump by saying he would name his next son after the spring. The women from Lower Woodlake had come with turnips and grief and were tending both in the same way, slow and stirring. When Lord Baeza tasted the soup he made the face of a man who has discovered his prejudice is not only foolish but a joke passed around avidly by the people he had thought to impress. He nodded. The cleric’s mouth softened into the shape that means this is not the worst place God ever invented and perhaps He knew what He was doing when He put the river here.

“Write your letter,” Dolores told Lord Baeza, because she was disinclined to let a man feel good for long without asking him to work. “Say you watched a hole refuse your flag and thought about your mother. Tell them not to send a bell tower. Tell them to send rope, thirty coils, and men who will not piss near oak. We have our own piss. We don’t need yours dressing up as aid.” She had her ledger out without seeming to and took down what she was owed in a neat hand that had frightened men into paying debts their grandfathers had stolen.

While men learned obedience to a girl’s rope and while soup became the philosophy of a crowd, Sid stood with Eryn under the lower oak where the ground still remembered the feet of a particular boy who had hid there with pears and a knife to carve his name into them so that when he ate he would also have taken a little of himself into himself. He had the ribbon Bee had tied in his mind and the knot had become a way of thinking. “You came when I asked,” he said, which is an accusation in a thousand small countries because it reveals the ask was heard.

She adjusted the cuff of her coat with an attention that had saved her life more than once. “I came because I don’t like losing the ability to surprise myself. I also came because men with salt in their ears are loud and you needed a woman in gray to stand to your left and make this look like more than farmers trying dignity on. Do not write me into your ledger as a kindness.” She tilted her head toward the bowl where the hum had gone quiet as if exhausted by introducing itself. “I sent two of mine up the north slope last night, past Piedra and on toward the old jam factory. They heard another song. Not the same note. A different jaw.” Her mouth made a shape she lent only to true confession. “If this is a mouth, it is part of a set. If this is a wound, it was made with a tool that likes to work in pairs.”

He watched her face while she said it and could not decide if he was glad to discover that fear had a shape he could hold or if he was being handed a map without creeks. “Second,” he said. The word sat in the air like a brick waiting to become a corner. “Then the law we make today will be tested tomorrow by men who don’t like waiting twice for anything. Then we need more rope, more soup, more jokes, more ways to say no without making it a war.”

“Perhaps also more beds that are not for sleep,” she said, deliberate and then not, because she had not meant to say it and needed him to know this was the part of her that said true things when she was bone-tired. “Because tired men become greedy for absolutes. If you avert two fights with a woman’s mouth or a man’s hand that has nothing to do with knives, you save a life. Put your jester in charge of the quiet corners. Make him hand out threads for people to braid so their hands will not want to throw.”

“I’ll make Tomas a priest of making the middle bearable,” Sid said. He did not let the image bloom and take his day. He kept it folded, like a letter you do not read again because the first time did something to your chest. “Can you go north and come back before night makes the world lie.”

“I can go north and come back if the world keeps its current bargains,” Eryn said. “The world owes me little. But I can collect on small debts. I will send a boy with a ribbon if I find a second bowl and he will tie it to the old gate at Piedra at the notch where you can’t see it unless you work with your hands. If I don’t send him, assume I am taking on work that has me for supper.” She touched her fingers to his shoulder and took them away again because she had learned that sometimes the body doesn’t know how to stop asking. “Do not make a speech,” she advised. “Men remember the wrong sentences. Simply say we are not naming anything until it tells us its name and then show them you can hold your tongue in your teeth. If you bleed a little from doing it, so much the better. People believe blood.”

He wanted to ask her what to name the second note if it was a jaw and how many jaws these hills could host before the city below them became one long mouth laughing itself into ruin. He wanted to tell her about his father cursing the water for being exactly as it should be, which is to say, without pity, and how he had inherited that kind of love and was trying to dress it in mercy. He wanted, which was becoming a real thing he had to reckon with, to put the ribbon she had not worn into her hair himself and be content with that action, small and ceremonial and useless against geology. He said instead, “No speeches. Soup. Rope. Girls who tie better than kings hold. That is my plan and I will lie to no one about the parts of it that are luck.”

By late afternoon the coastal men had learned to keep their weight back from the rope as if it could bite. The cleric had managed three mmhmms with grace and without performing sanctity for an audience; it made Sid look at him with the particular suspicion he reserved for decent men. Lord Baeza had taken his salt ring off for a while, because the hum made it ache in a way he would be embarrassed to describe to anyone, and he had hidden it in his pocket like an unwise letter. He had also taken a second bowl of soup and smiled at Bee with unwilling brotherhood after she salted it with a pinch from a horn she kept tucked in her boot. Tenorio had coaxed two shepherds into admitting what they had heard last winter near Piedra that they had not repeated because it had been the sort of noise you felt foolish connecting to anything. Marta had measured the slope with a string, a pebble, and patience, and drawn a triangle in the dust that made young men admire math.

Then the hum changed. It came low and then lower, and then another note rose, not harmony, not discord, but intersection. It came from the north. It came from a place that had not yet been asked to behave. Birds did the wrong thing in the wrong order. A coyote appeared on the ridge like an illustration of an idea and sat down and wove its ears in a figure eight and looked affronted at a world it had been counting on to be consistent. Men looked at each other the way men do when someone has suggested doing a dangerous thing together and their spines all try to leap up inside their skin in excitement and dread.

Eryn was already moving. She had not brought her mare into the first bowl because she had not been asked to and because there were promises made this morning she intended to honor at least until she had to break them. Now she whistled a note that came not from her throat but from the part of her mouth that had taught itself to be bird and thief and woman and girl. The gray mare came from behind a stand of willow where Santi had been trying to make a friend and failed because the mare did not think much of friendship in the middle of a crowd. Eryn put a hand to the horse’s neck and the animal put her head down to the knee and stood for the rope as if it had learned rope language and understood it was a treaty. She did not look back at Sid as she mounted. That would have made the thing sentimental and therefore less likely to end in survival. She looked ahead, and the mare shared her attention respectfully. She said a word that was not a name but would answer like one, and they went.

“North,” Sid said, not to no one, never to no one, because he had learned that kings who said things to no one were unwell. “Tomas, take Bee and Santi and Marta as far as the second bend and make a gate out of brush so the men who cannot stand not being first will find it hard to ruin themselves. Ajit, stand at the road and tell the next person who arrives that they have to hold someone’s hand before they can see anything and if they argue make them hold yours. They will learn humility and perhaps something about the worth of missing fingers. Dolores, I will write your name on a board so the boys we send to Woodlake can say something that sounds like law when they run with it.”

“You will sit and drink water,” Dolores said, because a steward’s job is to put water into the hands of whatever idiot is about to make the right decision at great cost. She thrust a skin at him that she had tied with Bee’s knot. He took it and tied it back to himself, and that loop across his shoulder felt like belonging and a collar and like every promise he had not known he made and would try to keep.

They could not leave the first bowl to go to the second without deciding what to call it in their mouths. They agreed on almost nothing except one thing, and that was that they would not teach it a name yet. The cleric wrote the not-name on his hand in invisible ink. Lord Baeza placed his ring back on and said a thing in his own language that had no vowels and made Ajit smile despite himself. Tenorio patted the ground as if he approved it for temporary occupation by idiots. Sid turned his face north and did not think about all the parts of him he was leaving on the hill tied to knots and ledgers and soup pots and men who thought they knew what a clam could do.

The lower road made a bend that had taught a thousand carts to be careful or to become stories. When they reached it, Bee and Tomas and Marta and Santi took apart a fence and wove it with brush into a gate that looked like it had been there all along and would only move for the hands of people who understood it, which is to say, people who would survive the next hour. They left two boys at it with hard candy and the authority of having been spoken to by Dolores. Meanwhile, Sid and a smaller group went on at a pace that made the horses lift their heads and remember they used to run for fun when they were wild and unshod. The light, this late, had an orange opinion about how far they should get and when they should turn back, and he ignored it because the note was still in his teeth and had to be investigated.

They found the second place before they saw it. It had the smell of old iron in rain even without rain. The grass had crouched, not laid down, as if expecting to be beaten without reason. The sound, when it came, was thinner, younger, a filament instead of a rope, and yet it threaded a man’s knees into his jaw exactly as efficiently. Eryn stood on a low rock with her mare’s rein in her hand and her head turned as if listening with the back of her neck. She glanced at Sid like a thief checking whether a boy would hold water in a paper bucket. He would.

This bowl was shallower; a dent, a cupping palm, not a mouth. The glass at the edges was not ironed as smoothly as the first; it was blistered, as if something had tried to come up and then forgot why. In the center, there was no curve. There was a straight piece of something black as any come-up-from-fire thing counts as black. It was not wood. It was not stone. It had edges like a tool and a skin like a secret.

“Jaw,” Tomas said under his breath, because fools name things quietly where kings refuse to.

“Spare your labels,” Eryn said, but without any real heat left in her, because the word had a way of thinking itself into a man’s mouth whether or not his better mind wanted it to.

Dolores arrived with a pencil that had been whittled down to resentment and a slate that had not. She began herself to write the same three rules and then added a fourth that made even the cleric nod without irony: No names until the hum says yes. She underlined it because underlining made men stop and squint and therefore gave them time to improve.

Night wanted them back at the first bowl where the soup smelled like a town doing its best. The second bowl wanted them to make a second camp and divide their company and their attention and their claims. Eryn said, as if she had not thought about it until three seconds ago and of course she had, “I will stay here with two of mine and Santi if he will. Bee goes back to feed people and sleep and tell jokes badly. Your jester stays where he can be seen because he keeps men from lighting fires just to see a glow. Your old man who listens to stone will split himself into advice and send some here with me and keep some for you and then sleep on his side so his ear is on the good earth. You, Sid, go back and be seen going back. People stay sensible when they can visualize a king’s posture.”

He considered refusing. He considered it as a petty thing and a large, stubborn, boyish thing. He let it go because he had enough stubborn in him for the part where he had to tell Lord Baeza to keep his flag rolled. He put his hand on Eryn’s forearm just a little lower than most men would, in the place that means I know you can break this limb and take my life with it if you think I will become a story you cannot stand. “If anything hums wrong,” he said, which was meaningless and therefore useful, “whistle the way you did for the mare. I will hear it in my teeth.”

She said, “Do not love me by being useful at unuseful distances,” which was cruel and kind and more honest than she owed him, and made a shape with her mouth that was almost a blessing and then wasn’t.

The stars came up as if mocked by the glass they had to compete with and tried hard and succeeded because stars are patient and hold grudges well. The valley down below made its noises and could not be coaxed into silence; there were parties and fights and births and one marriage that had been on again off again for three years and had decided now was as good a time as any for another try. The first bowl glowed in minds as people fell asleep. The second bowl did the same in the throats of those who hadn’t seen it yet; that was a particular cruelty, to dream of shapes you didn’t know and wake up knowing too much.

Sid walked back in the dark with Bee half-asleep on her horse and Tomas telling the low version of a joke to keep coyotes and men who wanted to be coyotes from thinking they owned the path. Ajit matched his stride, and the missing fingers were quiet. “Two,” Ajit said finally, not because it needed saying but because sometimes a word stops two men from becoming statues. “We have two. We’ll have a third. That’s the way of things, like gates. They go in threes because men flatter themselves they invent symmetry.”

“Let it not be a third,” Sid said, but without asking gods to intervene because he had already asked them to notice too much today. “Let it be the other half of a jaw if it must, and then a rest and an apology. We will not manage a third. We will manage two because we are already failing at managing one and we have proven ourselves capable of arithmetic.”

“You will sleep,” Ajit insisted, which he had no right to do and all the right. “You will put your head down in the room that makes you think of both your parents and you will not dream of edges. If you wake, you will not go to the window. You will go to your table and you will try to write a word for this and your pencil will break and you will take that as a sign and you will go back to bed. In the morning you will convene people and make a law that has soup in it. Put soup into law and you will cut arrests by a third.”

“Soup is an expensive statute,” Sid said, and then, because he had learned to be grateful when his friends made his mouth find jokes after a day that could have drowned it, “We will write it in the ledgers in the ink that doesn’t run when a man cries into it.”

“Use the old ink,” Ajit said. “The cheap that stains everything.” He blew out a breath through pursed lips and made a tune of it that Tomas took up with a hum not unlike the bowl’s smallest moment. “Two,” he repeated, and this time it had become a plan rather than a counting.

By the time they reached the yard under the tower the soup was down to thick edges and the last of it stuck to the side of the cauldron the way childhood sticks to a man who didn’t mean to carry it. Lord Baeza had not left. He had taken off his armor as far as decency could bear and was sitting with a woman from Lower Woodlake who was telling him a story about her son that contained no lesson he could use and would nevertheless alter how he spoke to men with blue stoles for a month. The cleric had found Tomas and the two of them had invented a game with pebbles and a circle and a lie, and they were cheating each other so elegantly that men who had been prepared to distrust both found themselves charmed and annoyed into a kind of peace.

Dolores put her hand on Sid’s wrist and squeezed once because an agreement had been made that they would not startle each other in public with anything like tenderness. “In the morning,” she said, “we tell men where to stand. We tell them what not to call it. We tell them that if they throw anything in, we will throw them in, and we say it like a jest so the ones who need to laugh can laugh and the ones who need to be afraid can find that in it. We tell them soup is law. Then you will sit and listen and say no three times and yes once, and then we will go to the second place and begin again.”

“I will also find a quiet corner for men who would otherwise make trouble,” Sid said. “Tomas, you are now the master of misdirection. You will lay out cloth and thread and the bones children like to string on cords, and you will say you are teaching men to make offerings because it will make them feel holy and therefore decent for twenty minutes.”

“I have always been a priest,” Tomas said, not bothering to rise to the bait because he knew his collar was a laugh. “Of the middle. Of the place between jokes and tears. Bring me old women with needles and young boys with pocketknives. I will save your law more effectively than anything written. I will even bless the salt man if he gives me a decent shell to hold candies.”

Lord Baeza raised his shell as if toasting from a distance without the sin of toasting with water. “I have a clam for you,” he said, and smiled a smile that would be a good one if he earned it. “Perhaps, wilderness willing, this place will not make me a worse man. That is more than I expected when I got up this morning and put my salt on.”

Sid would sleep. He would be loved improperly by the air that came through his window carrying dust and the talk of his city, and he would pretend not to listen to his own bones. In the courtyard, a boy finished washing the ladle because he had discovered that being the last to touch a thing made him important. In the north, under oaks, Eryn wrapped her scarf around her arm because she had no scarf about her throat and slept with one hand on the mare’s rein and one on dirt that had decided to behave for the next four hours. In the first bowl the glass cooled by a thought. In the second bowl something that was not stone learned the geography of waiting.

When the sun pulled itself up on Fresno’s chosen hooks, the men with white armor were already lined at the rope, the lemon light on their plates making them look like pastries left to harden. The city woke with its usual shouting and began to add a new sound to it, not yet a word, certainly not a name, but a syllable of the sort that becomes both, a sound that could be described as mmhmm if you had no poetry and as agreement if you were in love. Sid drank the water Dolores forced on him and then he went under the fig-painted crenels to say the three sentences in the simple nouns he and his steward had chosen and the one he had made for himself: we will go see. He said them without speechifying, without lifting his chin more than a man lifts it to make his voice carry, without any word that would make a wrapper for his fear. People listened because they were tired from a night of hearing a thing that was older than them pretend to be born. Then the day ran, because days do, and the law of soup did its secret work, and knots held men and their appetites, and the bowls sung as bowls teach a place to stand, and somewhere in the pairs of hum and reply a word began to grow that would not be trolleyed into market or written into ledger until it was ready, and that would be the reason people would say later that this was the moment when Fresno learned to keep its mouth and its wonder both, and that was how you survive a season in which dragons are a rumor and a habit.Chapter Seven

The morning took hold with both hands, and Fresno, who had learned to rise whether begged or bellowed at, rose under a sky the color of old denim worked soft by years of washing. Sid stood under the crenels where the royal blue peeled away in the shapes he named, wind tugging the brim of the woven hat he wore instead of copper, and he spoke the three sentences he and Dolores had scraped down to bone. No fire near the bowls. No going past rope tied by a child of this city. No digging until a stone-listener says the word that is not yet yes. He added the one sentence that was his and would be, he hoped, the kind that clung: we will not name a thing until it tells us its name. He said we will go see after, not as a flourish but as habit, and the people below in the market, who knew the taste of habit, let it settle on their tongues and found it acceptable. Someone in the back laughed at a child’s hat falling down over ears; someone else lifted a basket into shadow; a woman with her sleeves pushed to the elbow wiped her hands on an apron and nodded because this was not the worst set of orders she’d heard paired with dawn.

Dolores had already split chalk and slate into a dozen small edicts and put them under the arms of boys who had been taught by mothers to run without testing the leashes of their lungs. She had taken Bee’s words and Ajit’s cautions and Tenorio’s lore and made them walkable. There were three boards at the lower crossing and two at the upper, one nailed by Marta to a post that had outlived many signs and thought itself immortal. She had written the letters large and plain, and then she had made the children who carried them recite the rules until their mouths knew the shape better than a prayer. She sent the smallest boy with an old tin bell and told him where to ring it and where not to, and when he forgot, because small boys will, the rope Bee had tied kept his forgetting from becoming a tragedy. Between errands she required bread from a baker who had never been asked for anything without someone offering coins and who was surprised to find that being requisitioned by name and smile was a kind of currency he could accept.

Tomas laid out his cloth in the yard as if it were a map people might want to walk into. He had thread in colors acquired by methods no one wished to inspect, bones polished by fingers and river both, crackers wrapped in paper to bribe men into sitting awhile, and a bowl of buttons that had disagreed with their jackets. He told a boy with teeth like corn to string blue with black until his hands forgot to itch for stones to throw. He told a woman whose laugh had made winter bearable for three men to teach a half-dozen strangers how to braid a good rope, and when someone asked him what this had to do with dragons, he said, with sacred seriousness, that this had to do with the part of a day you spend not making enemies. He had a line of men pretending not to be waiting to sit by midmorning, each with a story they would not tell and a string they would.

Lord Baeza wrote his letter sitting on a spool of old cable that had pretensions to thronehood. He had a steady script, as if seas taught steadiness alongside sickness, and he told the Tidemark that the inland had grown a hum. He explained, in words that had the taste of his pride in them, that a girl’s knot made a better border than salt if men agreed to feel it. He requested rope, not banners, and two men with ears worth their keep rather than a cavalcade. He did not mention that the soup had been good, but when the cleric with the blue stole leaned over to read and saw that omission, he tapped the line where the word might belong and Baeza sighed and added, by the way, their soup is not an offense to our name. Ajit brought him a cup of water and a piece of advice about inland rules wearing grudges, and Baeza surprised himself by saying thank you as if the road were a room he wished to be invited into again.

Tenorio found a child who would listen. She was eight and called Luz by a grandmother who had known the taste of light after the Breakage, and she had a way of standing that told a man she annexed information without paying full tax. He gave her a shallow pan filled with dirt from three places and a drum head stretched tight over a hoop that had once held a barrel of oil. He let a few grains fall on the drum and then hummed soft and she saw the grains walk, saw the pattern his voice made, saw that the pattern was different when he shifted his throat. He did not tell her she had learned a word. He told her she had learned how to spell an old word with new dust. Luz considered him solemnly and told him that if the earth was going to sing then the people should learn to harmonize instead of shouting. He nodded as if he had been waiting all morning for someone to say that so he could rest.

Up at the second bowl Eryn stood with the gray mare’s rein looped over a rock and Santi at her shoulder like an agreement he hadn’t wanted and decided to honor anyway. She had two of hers in the scrub—Lark with the quick hands and the sorrow he wore lightly, and Pina, whose smile was a tricky thing that had bought them time in three towns and nearly got them killed in a fourth. Eryn had wrapped the gray scarf around her bared head this time because the sun had decided to practice cruelty before noon, and she had wound the tail of it around her wrist in a knot that would let her pull it loose if someone tried to use it to make her obey. The hum here was thinner, a wire strung across a canyon as yet unnamed. It came up through her spine and made her teeth want to confess and then apologize for confessing. Santi stood as he had stood beside his wife’s body the day he had learned widowhood as a word that didn’t know him and made itself known anyway, with his hands quiet and obedient and his face giving nothing but a willingness to weather.

They walked the rim the way you walk the edge of a conversation you do not trust, looking for the places where language thins. The black straight piece in the bowl was not a root, not a pipe, not a blade as Eryn’s knife-hand wished to call it for the satisfaction of knowing how to resist it. It did not take light. It accepted it. Eryn put her palm to a shard of glassed dirt and then took it away with a hiss, not of pain but of insult; the earth did not usually mind being touched by her and today it had decided it had preferences. Pina, who had been a weaver before the Breakage took her loom and traded it for two goats and a man’s temper, crouched and studied the long edge of the black. She whispered that if you ran your eyes along it quick and then slower you could feel it sit in two times at once, which was a nonsense that nobody laughed at on the lip of a bowl.

Down in the city a deputation from the Fig Guild came to the courthouse with fruit in hand and grievance in mouth. They brought a crate of the first bruised sweetness and offered it like a bribe to the idea of fairness. They complained that ropes were a fashion that would cost them dearly because knots meant delays and delays meant birds with audacity; they claimed that soup was all well and good until it took a bag of beans that could have been planted instead of boiled. Dolores listened as a woman listens when she has a child on her lap and a ledger in her head and a lock to her left and a jar of pickles that is not for today on the shelf above her. She assured them that soup could be made from ends and bones and not from their profits and that the ropes were there because men liked to run toward holes as if a hole would make them full. Ajit arrived with a bag of split peas in one hand and a cypress sprig in the other and told the fig men that if they sent boys to the bowls with ladders he would use those ladders to fix their broken culverts and in the evening he would sit on their porch and count with them how many gallons had been saved. They looked at Sid to see if he would be the kind of king who bowed to fruit, and he smiled at the figs because they had fed him as a boy and said, dignities will be met with dignities, and when you are right, Dolores tells me, and when you are wrong, she tells me louder.

In Market Lane a man named Esteban of Coppergate sold vials of soot as suckle-ash taken from the dragon’s breath and promised it would make hens lay and wives forgive. Tomas bought one and opened it and smelled it and declared it to be stove. Ajit, who had spent the dawn freeing a jammed gate with his remaining fingers and a dictionary of curses he had acquired from seven cultures, pinched a bit of the ash between thumb and forefinger and smudged it on his wrist where the old burn lay and said without drama that dragon ash would not make a gaiter stain like that. He fined Esteban a morning’s worth of hauling water to the soup pots and gave his soot vials to a boy who would make a fine ink with them if he was given the chance. Esteban argued until Tomas whispered to him a better business: little jars of market dust to keep in a pocket and remember belonging when a man had to walk away for a while. Esteban did not thank him, but later he left a jar with a cork tied by a ribbon near the cloth where Tomas sat, and Tomas took it and looked at it as if it were the neatest idea in ten days.

Bee ran the old canal like a girl who was learning the gravity of being trusted and enjoying every part of it. She tied ribbon at the turn where dirt learned to lie and at the crack in the gate post that looked like a man’s face and at the fence line where the neighbor’s wife had a habit of hanging laundry with pins made from apple wood. At the last she met a boy with calves like bent nails and a mouth that had not given up yet on being kind by accident. His name was Ivo, which sounded like an oath and a promise both. He was trying to slip the rope and prove something to his taller cousins, and Bee caught him not by the arm but by the word. She told him to help her tie instead and he did, and after an hour he had decided that ropes were better than daring because they let daring have a yard to romp in without getting cut by glass. He took the piece of ribbon she gave him as if it was a responsibility, which is a phenomenon you cannot sell in vials.

At the first bowl, not long after noon, a man too warmed by the common courage of soups and jokes tried to throw a stone because temptation is a muscle you must bruise early. The rope tugged his hips forward gently at first, like a mother pulling a child back from the curb, and then harder, because he insisted. It looked like a magician’s trick; it was a knot that Bee had taught with a glare. Tenorio told a story from his chair, not loud and not long, about a hill that had eaten a wagon wheel because the wheel had been pointing in the wrong direction for a century and was tired. The man sat down and unlearned the itch in his arm without being scolded. The cleric built a moment of silence with his mmhmm and the young ones around him mimicked it because it felt like power without shouting and that was rare enough to be a novelty. For a little while the place was a classroom men had made for themselves without anyone in it owning chalk.

At the second bowl toward evening Eryn felt a new kind of breath come through the ground. It did not push. It asked. The birds did not fall out of it; they hesitated in it. The black straight thing in the center did not lift but it made its edges known to the dust and the dust, civilized by the lesson, arranged itself along lines Eryn could recognize by the face she made when she saw men put their knives in order instead of leaving them like bones thrown to dogs. She forbade Santi’s hand without looking. He had been thinking of touching. His fingers stopped. Lark’s mouth formed a word he did not speak because on some days the hum taught him his own name too loudly. Eryn let the wanting-to-know go through her and not out, which is what you have to do when you want to live long enough to find out anything of worth. She pulled the gray scarf twice tight around her wrist to remind herself she was still attached to this day and not some other.

By the time the message reached Sid it was a knot on a rope with an extra twist in it Bee had invented for urgency and trust. It had been tied by Pina and carried by Pico, a boy from the slope who could run a hill like a breath taken correctly. He did not come into the hall; he left the knot on the old gate by the plow wheel where Dolores had told him anything tied would be treated as a summons. Sid found it between a levy calculation and a kindness he had intended to pay and kept forgetting. He untied it and read it with his fingers the way men learn to read rope when letters feel like ceremonies for other people. Eryn was staying. The second bowl had shifted the way a sleeper shifts without waking. It wanted witness, not interruption. Pico had added a twist of his own that meant hunger, and Sid smiled because that was the part of this any king could fix.

What he could not fix arrived with bells no one had asked for. They were not coastal bells. They were Dust Monks, who were not monks in any rigorous sense except that they preferred to love from a distance and then come closer with bowls. They wore robes washed thin by sand, carried mirrors framed in cracked wood, and sang a low chant that had learned a folk song on a long road and refused to leave it. They wanted to see the hum to decide if it was the kind of hum their founder had meant when he’d said the earth would one day speak because it was tired of men saying it wrong. They wanted to hold their mirrors up to the bowl to see if humility could be reflected and they wanted to call it a lesson if it could not. Dolores met them at the rope with a ledger and a smile that had no blood in it, because her job on days when men thought themselves holy was to pour sand on their sparks until they thought themselves useful. She told them no mirrors inside the rope because mirrors make small suns and they weren’t in the business of building new ones. The leader of the group, a woman called Sister Vero because she did not lie and made you wish you hadn’t either, asked if she could sit close and say nothing. Tenorio permitted it as he would permit a neighbor’s gourd in his garden if the neighbor promised to pick it when it was ripe.

By late afternoon a rumor of a man Eryn did not love more than policy arrived at the second bowl. He rode a bay with a tail that had been cut for practicality and spite and wore three rings in his left ear that had never healed properly and so bled when he was angry. His name was Gavino and he was the sort of thief who thought waiting his turn made him weak. He had been a friend to nothing that could not be folded into his pocket and passed off as being a poem. He smiled at Eryn with the teeth of a little fish that has survived by never attempting to be bigger. He informed her that he and his would be lowering pigs into the hole morning after next, to prove it was a saint’s mouth and therefore their parish’s business. Eryn did not take her knife out because she had decided this hour to not give a man the dignity of a threat. She offered him soup which he refused because the spoon was in her hand and not his. She advised him in front of Santi’s patient eyes that lowering pigs is a quick way to learn the phrase no one comes to your funeral. He told her to come see him when she had grown out of courtesy and rode away with his ear bleeding from the pressure of his temper on his rings.

Sid called a hearing under the north oak at twilight when heat had loosened its grip enough to be ashamed of itself. He did not sit on the plow throne; he stood with one hand on the oldest scar in the bark and the other on Rosales’s knife because that combination of the old and the sharp made him feel constructed correctly. Representatives came because names give men reasons to say they deserve to, and they said them. Fig Guild. Sheep. Salt. Dust. Stone-listeners. The women who keep graves. The three old men who sang on Wednesdays and had come to accept that no verdict was complete without them harmonizing at the end. He made a new oath that would be called a small thing later when people who had not been there wanted to feel larger. He said that any rope tied by a child of Fresno was law where law might otherwise not exist, and that to untie it without permission would cost a week of carrying water and a day of sweeping the courtyard and a night of singing until your throat remembered you had a body. He made soup an instrument, not of order, but of intention, and that is what instruments are, and he wrote it down with the cheap ink Ajit swore by so the words bled into the page and would not look neat when the page got wet. He asked Tenorio and Marta to make of their listening a guild and offer apprenticeships paid in bread and glory, and both said they preferred glory to come later. He affirmed the coastal men a place at the rope and took from them the right to speak to market about anything but what soups they had tasted. He did not say Eryn’s name and everyone he loved knew it and did not make him pay for it publicly.

At dawn the next day he learned what tremors meant when they did not end where you could see them. The gate at Walnut Skew shuddered and Ajit caught the chain with what fingers he had and dragged it into obedience while swearing he would have a fourth and fifth son to name after this day and he was not in the business of sons. The bowls answered each other like voices across a house, not singing yet but trying out sound as a method of affection or warning. The hum rolled under the city and shook a cupboard in a woman’s kitchen so that her cups clinked and she decided to forgive her neighbor a debt simply because she liked the singing of it. Tenorio stood in the yard and turned slow and pointed his chin east and said it was rolling that way, which meant the next moment would have a choice to make. Lord Baeza, who had sailed through weather that tore sails like confessions, said under his breath that this was a tide inside the land, which made Ajit look at him and smile like a man recognizing a craft when he had only seen wood before.

Eryn spent the hour before noon with the kind of attention that wrings sweat out of a person who is only standing still. The second bowl had begun to change. You could not watch it do it. You had to turn away and then check and then know it had moved and feel both relieved and angry, which is how a city grows and a woman makes a decision she knows will cost her. The black edge lifted up the thickness of a thumb and sank back as if reconsidering. A swipe of wind came from the center without bringing the smell of heat, and the grass along the rim leaned north as if being taught a lesson by a stern aunt. Santi placed a stick at the edge and marked it with his knife and when it moved, he marked again and sang a song under his breath to make the marks into a story and not a panic. Eryn crouched like a prayer and put her palm near, not on, and the air on her skin felt like metal might if metal were ashamed of itself for loving softness. She took a stone the size of an apricot, wrote her name on it with the ink Esteban had started making for the market, and put it in her pocket because sometimes the only way to be a seamstress in a life that keeps handing you knives is to plan to stitch something later with symbols foolish enough to believe in you.

The Dust Monks almost undid an afternoon just by being themselves. They held up their mirrors not toward the bowl but toward the faces staring at it, and people started seeing themselves and that is often a spark you cannot count on to behave. A child squealed because her hair stood on end without anyone’s permission, and three boys laughed and then made their own hair stand as a way of courting the hum into thinking they were grown. Sister Vero found Tomas and told him in the tone of a woman confident you will hear her that their founder had said the day would come when the earth would ask us to speak quieter. Tomas pointed toward the soup kettles and told her the same thing in Fresno, and she lifted her mirrored bowl gently and went to sit by the rope and did not make ceremony of it. The hum in that hour ran along the edge of the cities people had within themselves, and a few of those edges softened and retained the softness and a few cut deeper to prove that steel was still a possibility here among goats and figs.

There were negotiations with God, because there always are. The cleric with the blue stole told his god who loves a horizon that he had found one in a bowl and he was trying to pretend that wasn’t possible but his chest felt better when he leaned into the pretense. He offered the hum his mmhmm, which is a prayer you can take anywhere without breaking it, and it came back to him as a change in pitch that made him feel like a child hearing an adult sing badly and trying to match it. In the night he dreamed of water sitting in a stone cup without becoming less itself and woke to write that down shamefaced because it looked, in moonlight, like an attempt at a poem. He did not show it to Tomas. Tomas would have either praised it and ruined it or mocked it and made it better.

Under the north oak Sid and Dolores drafted, by lantern and biting flies, the Rope Oath in a copy that would be hung at the courthouse and in two copies that would be tucked inside cookie tins because Dolores trusted tins with the kind of loyalty she did not extend to stapled parchments. The oath said that you owed your city one hour of sitting still at a rope for every rumor you spread, and men laughed but they sat when asked because cords need weight to show they can hold. It said that soup could settle three disputes a day and no more, because soup runs out and so should argument, and for the overflow there were pebbles and a circle and a game taught by a fool who would let you cheat as long as you did it with style. It said the bowls would be considered graves when the women who kept graves said so, and until then they were considered markets where no one could sell anything but patience.

Eryn and Santi set their watch in thirds as if this were winter and the thing they were guarding against was hunger instead of curiosity. Around the second bowl they put little bells that Pina made from bottle necks and twine, low, at shin height, so that a man with intent would sing his malicious tidings before he got where he meant to go. In the dark a coyote sang that figure eight again, long ears weaving the air, and Pina said without irony that perhaps the coyotes were the form the hum would take when it decided to walk. Santi told her not to give the world ideas. Eryn slept four times for ten minutes and woke four times feeling guilty for the seconds she had abandoned the city. Guilt is a thread, and she rolled it around her wrist and made it into a bracelet rather than a noose because she had learned to dress herself on mornings she had not chosen.

Near midnight the first bowl answered the second with a sound like a cart being pushed over worn wood and everyone who had ever pushed a cart that rattled in quite that way felt the insult and the compliment of recognition. The hum moved through the sleeping like a cat deciding which lap is best and some people dreamed of teeth and some dreamed of smooth edges and some did not dream at all because not dreaming is sometimes how a person keeps a day from taking all of them. Sid woke twice and did not go to the window, which made him feel like a man who had learned the smallest part of a thing he had promised to learn. He went instead to his table and his pencil broke and he laughed under his breath because Ajit had called it and because even if he had not he would have felt the world telling him, not everything needs a word tonight.

At dawn, when the sky wore a pale ridge of light that would turn to gold if you were lucky and to glare if you were not, Eryn stood with her hand on the gray mare’s flank and her eyes on the black and she felt it decide something without telling her what that something was. The straight lifted again the width of a fingernail and set back down and when it did a breath came up that smelled like fennel that had been burned in a kitchen where someone had argued and then wept. She had planned three moves ahead of such a thing and none quite matched what she had been given, which is how you know you are alive and not a script. She whistled not the mare’s call but a note she had made for emergencies and raised her hand not to shade her eyes but to hail a messenger only she could see. In the city a boy untied a ribbon from a post and began to run. Sid, who had been about to say his four sentences again at the courthouse because the second day is when men forget, put his hand on the words and held them still. He felt the pull that had nothing to do with lust and everything to do with obligation and desire having discovered they could share a chair for the space of an hour.

The day stretched itself thin and did not tear only because so many hands held it up. The law of soup did its secret arithmetic, subtracting two fights for every ladle. The rope held foolishness by the waist and made it laugh and sit down. The salt men learned, to their surprise, to look without planning where to put a foundation, and Lord Baeza wrote a second letter that used the word listen twice and his own men did not rib him for it because they, too, had felt the quiet without the sense of loss that came with quiet at sea. Tenorio taught Luz to hear the difference between a warning and a pronouncement and Luz went home and taught her mother and her mother taught the neighbor and soon there were twenty more ears in the city that were tools and not ornaments. Ajit promised a gate to a woman who had never been promised anything and then made it, and when it broke he fixed it without telling anyone and he felt afterward that he had done something both religious and rude.

Near sunset, when men made themselves bigger with shadows, Gavino’s watchers showed themselves at the second bowl in the least imaginative way. They found their harnesses snagged by Pina’s bells and every step turned them into goats announced by tin. Eryn, who had perfected the art of making scorn into medicine, offered them bread and water and asked the name of their mothers and learned it and used it in a sentence in a tone you cannot buy and cannot fake. They untangled themselves from their humiliation and decided to wait until night to be foolish. Santi saw one look toward the black as if wishing to throw a crowbar at it and he walked into that look and stood there until the man’s glance went dull. Three times a woman from Piedra came up the road to stare and cry and stare and not cry and Eryn stood beside her and looked with her and did not ask because asking is sometimes just laziness dressed as care.

In the yard under the fig-painted crenels, Sid sat with his people and ate soup and bread and listened to men tell each other what they had almost done and how they had saved themselves from it. He told Tomas to claim a corner of the courthouse for a guild of hands that kept people from setting fire to their own hair, and Tomas said he would hang a bell and if you rang it he would give you thread and a song, and if you rang it twice he would make you sit until your fury remembered it once had been love. Dolores washed her chalk-stained fingers and said quietly that they would need more tins for their laws because paper didn’t hold under the weight of days like this. Rosales came by with the knife’s twin and told Sid her grandmother had been humming all afternoon and when Sid said he knew, she meant the old woman had been alive in her, and he smiled because he had not known but now he did and that is a kind of miracle you can claim without owing anyone coins.

He went to sleep with the hum under him like a river were the bed it had always claimed to be and he let the desire to go north and stand beside the woman who had made a rule of staying where he could not see her be what it was. He did not tell himself stories meant to make his wanting noble. He put the want on the sill where the moon could see it and judge him and he lay down without reaching for it and that felt like using the better tool in a box he finally admitted he owned. Eryn, under oaks, threaded a bit of string through the hole in a button because her hands needed to practice what they insisted they were meant for, and she made a small ragged bracelet and tied it around Santi’s wrist like a joke and not, and he accepted it with the gravest face to save them both from embarrassment. The hum rose once more like a thing learning to speak polite and swallowed its own name, and for a moment, in two places that had never been the same place and never would be, a king and a thief kept their mouths and their wonder both, and that was the only right way to end a day like this before beginning the next.Chapter Nine

They learned the sound of a morning that arrived already carrying something. Fresno’s sun climbed up with a stiffness it had not confessed to in years, and the sky was the pale of a healed bruise. Sid stood under the fig-painted crenels with the woven hat tugged low and the taste of old copper in his mouth as if he had bit a coin in his sleep. He said the four sentences because discipline is the only muscled prayer he believed in, and the market heard them without surprise and with relief. People do not mind being reminded of the same small kindnesses if the day ahead threatens large unkindnesses. Dolores sent the bell boy with the tin and sent two girls with chalk and sent a man with a voice that reached four streets to sit by Tomas and learn to speak at a volume that took the place of shouting. Sid watched the faces lift and lower and settle around his words and he thought bitterly and fondly of soup. He thought if he ever managed another decade in this city he would have to build a statue to a pot.

By the second hour the north wind did a new thing; it arrived and then stopped and then remembered itself and came again without malice. Tenorio turned toward the hills and cupped his good ear as if catching the day like a fly. “It’s rolling like a barrel you shouldn’t have let your cousin seal,” he said, and the sheep men laughed without threat because that was exactly the feeling and because metaphors could be tools when the right calluses wielded them. Ajit had been counting while other men listened. He had his chalk on the cobbles and his gate schedules in his head and the taste of grit at the back of his throat where paper turns to reluctance. “It will take the pressure at Walnut Skew and at La Palma both,” he told no one and Dolores at once. “If the hum runs under at the same rate as the flow, we can teach the gates to breathe, and if it doesn’t, we can teach men how not to panic while they pretend they did.”

Dolores sent a boy for Rosales and sent a woman to bring Ajit the flat bread he forgot and sent a note to the women who kept the graves written in the polite hand she used for saints. She knew the city as a box of moving pieces that would disobey if you bullied and would work miracles if you asked with the tone their grandmothers used on them when they were eight. She drafted, in between three orders and two jokes, the beginnings of an ordinance she told no one she was writing: the Breath Law, which would tell men that some days were for opening without fear and some days were for shutting without bravado, and which would be useless until someone made a ritual of it.

At the second bowl a man made of excuses and cheap metal arrived with dawn still arguing in his hair. Gavino brought two pigs in a cart with slats and the sort of ropes that fray their own ends in impatience. He had three men and the certainty that doing the wrong thing quickly would count as faith if you held your chin high. Pina’s little bells told on them three steps before they showed their faces and Santi had his hand on the cart before any boast found breath. Eryn took her scarf off her head for the first time that day so the wind could see that she had come bare and not to threaten, and she smiled a smile that men have left rooms to avoid and then stayed awake thinking about. “You lower anything into this,” she told Gavino, “and it will not be pigs that come back out changed. It will be your name. It will be the way your mother is greeted at the well.”

Gavino looked at Santi because men like him always look to find the crack in another man’s patience. Santi’s face said it had outlived winter, a fever, the kind of hunger that makes a man want to lie to himself, and a woman he had loved for a long time dying anyway. It said today was not the day a boy with too much jewelry made it worse. “Hear our bells,” Santi said, and his voice was so even it might have been a level held against a wall. “We will untie them for you and let you go back down the road with your pigs alive if you leave before the wind changes. If you push, we will push. We are past the hour where I will be made ashamed of the care I take for things I don’t understand.”

Pina flipped her knife end over end and caught it by the safe part and then showed Gavino the thing she had made from bottle necks and twine. “Mine rings louder than your name,” she said, and there was no pride in it because it wasn’t pride, it was fact. The pigs snorted because pigs have the good sense to be afraid of bowls that hum. Gavino held his jaw where the rings bit and let his pride do the arithmetic. Eryn waited him out because patience had won her more arguments than knives ever had, and when he snarled something about coming back and making parish business of this, she did not look at the men he would rouse. She looked at the women who would be made to sweep after him. She said quietly, “You bring a priest with a bowl and we will let him sit and mmhmm, and if he blesses your rope I will cut it and feed it to your pig and call it a consecration.” He left because there is a kind of dignity in retreat when done before witnesses and because Santi did not take his hand off the cart.

At the first bowl they discovered that law was better obeyed when it was sung. Tomas took Dolores’s slate and wrote the rope oath as if it were verse and then made the three old men sing it without harmony and without shame. Men laughed and then found themselves mouthing it, and when a stranger came with a hand reaching past Bee’s knots, three people in three different languages said the same sentence with the same ends and the man’s hand learned shyness. Sister Vero folded her mirror up in a square of cloth and sat without proselytizing because the hum that morning made its own sermon and she was tired of competing with elements. She said two lines of her founder’s saying and then substituted a third she invented that moment: that the holiness we fear might be nothing but attention.

Lord Baeza’s men arrived near the hour that made flies bold. They did not carry a bell tower; they brought coils of rope that had the good smell of tar and winter hands. They brought two men whose ears sat on their heads like tools rather than ornament, and when Tenorio looked at them he did the old man’s version of nodding approval—he spat with precision and did not smile. The two stone-listeners sat with Luz and her drumskin and treated the child as an apprentice rather than an audience, which made half the men nearby take them seriously. Baeza himself had learned to stand back from the rope without looking forced, and when a saltman new to inlanders stepped too close, Baeza caught his shoulder and squeezed in a manner that carried a map of limits. “We’re guests,” he said, and he did not like the words but he practiced them.

Ajit made the gates breathe. It was not as pretty as priests would have wanted. He ran, which is undignified in a man over forty who has carried chains with his teeth. He shouted when shouting would save a minute. He handed a boy his shirt to carry because it would slow him and he did not like the feeling of skin announcing itself but you do what you have to do when the river makes new ribs. He took Walnut Skew’s chain with his three fingers and the rope of his forearm and the anger he had at iron that thought itself superior, and he timed the drop to the hum. It felt wrong and then it felt right and then it felt like nothing and then he realized his teeth had stopped hurting. He sent a runner to La Palma with a sequence written as if it were a poem a drunk could keep in his mouth and told him to recite it at every culvert. He did not know whether he was worshiping, but it had the same posture.

The women who kept the graves came in their working dresses and the shoes they were not afraid to get wet. They stood at the rope and said nothing for a long while and then asked for a bench because sisters do not stand when they can sit and still be more imposing than any man in armor. Dolores fetched a bench and then another and then a third and she did not gossip near them. They argued in the dignity of low voices about what a grave was and whether a place where no one had been laid down yet could be one. At last the eldest, whose hair had been white since a morning forty years ago and who had a habit of mispronouncing the names of men who lied to her, tapped the rope as if asking permission to enter a thought. “We will not call this a grave,” she said, and two other women nodded because she had not got ahead of herself. “We will call it a mourning ring. People will bring what grief they cannot pour anywhere else and leave it here, and that will keep them from pouring it on their children. We will sit where the ring begins and we will sit where it ends and when it becomes a grave we will tell you and you will believe us.”

When the hum rose midday, the lattice returned in the dust and stayed a breath longer. Luz put her fingertips on her drum and hummed a note that matched and the grains arranged themselves into a different geometry, like ribs in a chest made of judgement. Tenorio’s eyelids fluttered in that ridiculous way that makes you think of birds. “It’s counting,” he said, and it was not a useful sentence until he said, “it counts to three and then insists on two and then rests, which means the next place will try to be new and then remember it has a twin and then we will have to hold our mouths and not say what comes after twin.”

Bee, who had been told all morning to drink water and had obeyed because she remembered what it was to not have it to obey with, leaned over the drum and hummed a harmony. The grains shivered and made a pattern like a net laid wrong. Ajit held his schedule in his head and said, with the same voice he said gate, “At the third note we release at North Sluice for two minutes and catch at Dredge Street for seven. We will do this three times. We will pretend to be clever and later we will write down what we did and call it an instruction for men who don’t like being told that bodies can be instruments.”

They did it. The canal let out and took in in a way that made the water remember being a hand. The hum slid under the city and did not catch in places where it could have. A cup in a woman’s house chimed against another and then stopped. A man who had tied a bucket to a rope asked his daughter to sing while he pulled and she did and the note made him cry, which embarrassed him and then did not. Sid watched Ajit’s throat move with the work and thought that if he lived to be old he would train boys up to bring the man he loved more than he knew to water and give him easy days. He thought this in the middle of a crisis and that is how you know he was in it for the long shape, not the short noise.

By late afternoon, when the light tried to make men handsome and failed at all but a few, Sister Vero stood and asked in her mild assaulting way to speak. The rope had taught her gentleness without making her feel diminished and she found she liked that trick. She told the gathering that her founder had said the earth would speak when tired, yes, but also that the conversation most worth having would be the one you made in your mouth when you told yourself the story of what you were seeing. “If we say dragon and we mean fear,” she said, “we will be given fear. If we say dragon and we mean wonder, we will be given wonder. If we say breath and mean law, we may be given enough time to make one.” It was not eloquent. It was not even new. It made three men who were about to do a stupid thing sit on their hands and unlearn the urge for thirty breaths and that bought someone else time to build a fence of questions.

On the north road a cart came with parts of a bell tower wrapped in canvas because men never believe you when you tell them you do not need a bell. Lord Baeza intercepted them with the easy impatience of a captain who has brought his ship into a dock that pretends to be a wall. He told them there were bells enough in men’s throats and that hanging a weight from a roof over a hole would make the hole a person and they were not electors of that person. The men argued and then were outnumbered and then decided to be merchants and sell the canvas as shade for the soup pot, which turned them from opposition into assets and Tomas congratulated them on their conversion. He set their pole aside and tied a string of bones to it and called it a shrine to patience and they threw him a curse and then a coin and then a grin.

At the second bowl the wind went east and brought the smell of something that had never been alive. Eryn had expected it and hated that about herself. The black straight piece lifted three fingernails thick and settled back with a grace that made all the hairs on her arm salutes of their own. Pina hissed the word that meant stop without making a sound and the boys in the scrub froze like deer who had learned to be predators for a moment. Santi marked another line in the dirt and head-counted without moving his chin because he took census seriously only when bodies were at stake. Eryn felt, in that instant, the peculiar sistole of a day that refuses to be linear. She wanted to be everywhere—the first bowl to see if the lattice changed its mind, the second to see if the edge would confess, the lower farms to catch the man now pouring too much water, the fig orchard because it had been where she had made a mistake and mistakes call you like home. She stayed. She held her breath. She did not give the bowl any names in her head. The hum accepted the lack with gratitude the way a child accepts not being told their own story wrong.

Sid arranged what he could call a council only because people needed it called something. The women with the graves bench sat at his left and the salt men leaned on their elbows at his right and Tenorio had placed himself where he would be seen without being adored. Ajit, with a rag around his neck that had been dipped in river to stop him from boiling, stood behind Sid like a wall you only build in your first season as king and then never again because you learn to trust the building to be where you left it. They made the Breath Law into paper and then into the tin. Dolores enlisted the boy with calves like bent nails to carry the tin to the fig orchard where another could be placed by the plow throne so that the law would be in two places at once and therefore believed. Tomas ringed the tin with thread in a color he announced as unnameable and when someone said it was just green, he said that was the point, that names hide as often as they reveal.

By the third day’s dusk, the city had grown quiet in a new way. It was not sulking. It was not waiting to explode. It was the quiet of a kitchen that has fed too many and then washed the last ladle. Bee had taught three boys how to tie the knot that turns a rope from a suggestion to a refusal, and she had taught a girl how to tell a man to sit without making him feel like a donkey and the girl had tried it on Tomas and Tomas had sat and it had been a good performance all around. Lord Baeza had sent his second letter and received, impossibly quick, an answer tied to a messenger’s belt in seal skin that smelled like apologies. It said rope more than once. It said there would be money and there would not be priests unless the inland asked. It was a letter meant to be seen by a king and by a woman with chalk and by the market that liked to make a day into a story.

That was when the clean fire came down the ridge. It did not look like fire. It looked like a shimmer over dry grass. It made a coyote’s outline into a lesson and then let the coyote yelp and run and leave behind a smell like burnt fennel and embarrassment. The wave carried no light of its own and it touched the rim of the first bowl and the rim hissed and then calmed, and every mouth in the yard made the little oh that people make in churches and bedrooms and over broken things. Tenorio held out his hand. His rings, which he wore not for decoration but because his fingers thought better when they remembered the weight of metal, sang in his bones. He swore once, honestly, and pulled them off and put them in Dolores’s palm because women who keep books and soup can keep other valuables in a way men will not consider theft. “No metal at the rope,” he said, and the sentence cut three foolishnesses in half where they stood.

The cleric put his whalebone ring in his pocket and glowed slightly from the relief of being told what to do that made immediate sense. Lord Baeza took the plates off his men with motions that suggested intimacy between commander and commanded and set them aside gently as if the straps were tendons and would remember cruelty. Ajit looked down at his chain and did not flinch at the way his missing fingers felt like doctrine. He said to the boys at the gates, “Leather wraps today. You hold with cloth. Your mother’s aprons will save you and you will return them washed.”

Eryn saw the shimmer at the second bowl lift a grass’s width of dust and settle and she taught her breath to obey manners. She sent Pico down with a knot to tell Sid what she could not dictate. She put her body between the black edge and the place where a boy would be stupid because she had been that boy at other times of her life and a body in the way always helps. Santi took his bracelet—the ragged string Eryn had made there in the dark—and tied it around the new stake he had set to mark the change so that anyone who did not think much of men would be told by thread what needed not doing. Pina snapped at Lark because he had reached for a rock with the old, terrible itch in his fingers, and he held his hand back and made a small noise because he had almost understood himself. They did not call it miracle and they did not call it curse. They called it noon-at-dusk and this is how language earns its bread.

When night put its full weight on the ridge, Sid walked as far as he could before duty made a leash of his ankle and he stopped under a tree that had been there before he had words. The air was a kind of friend who had not seen him for three days and intended to remind him he was mortal. He thought, because he was trying to live, of ordinary things: of the sound the stoneware made when Dolores put it on the board a little too hard at the end of a day; of the way Ajit sighed when a gate obeyed; of the face Santi had made at soup as if he were trying to decide between gratitude and grief; of Bee tying a knot as if she could tie time; of Tenorio setting his rings aside with the face of a priest turning from the altar to the basin; of Lord Baeza eating bread and pretending to disapprove of it and then asking for another piece; of Sister Vero watching her mirror reflect nothing and deciding that was the point; of Eryn’s hand on her own wrist holding her scarf on not as fashion but as restraint. He did not go to the window when he lay down. He put his hand out on the bed where something might lie and he did not lie to himself about who he wanted to be there or what that would cost.

On the fourth morning a deputation from the women of Lower Woodlake arrived with a question and an answer folded into it. They asked whether the mourning ring could also be a place to lay down promises and they answered themselves by laying down three: that no child of theirs would go to the rope without a mother’s word; that no man would set a fire in anger inside the smell of soup; that when the bowls named themselves they would listen and say the names right even if those names were hard. Sid wrote them into the tin because some words need to rattle to feel real. Dolores wrote them onto a slate because slates do not get rebuked by rain. Tomas wrote them on a piece of ribbon and gave it to a boy and told him to tie it to anything that would not be improved by a knot, and the boy tied it to his own wrist and declared himself a draft horse and was not entirely wrong.

The third place announced itself before noon by not being a place. It was a line two fields long where the earth sighed and dropped the thickness of a man’s hand, and the grass laid itself flat as if measuring fabric. Ajit felt it in the backs of his knees. Tenorio heard it in his good ear like someone dragging a chair on a floor in the next room, the old complaint of wood. The hum in the bowls did not rise to meet it; it let the line be. There was relief in that. There was also the knowledge that whatever was beneath them did not intend to be mapped on anyone’s schedule but its own. Dolores sent two boys with chalk and told them to mark both ends and then sit on the chalk to make it a place, because place is a thing you decide as much as a thing that happens.

Eryn walked the new line and looked at the way the cracks refused to be dramatic. She had tended to love only the dramatic because it had been a way of insisting she was alive when the quiet tried to convince her otherwise. Now she made friends with modest rupture. She knelt and pressed her fingers to the least interesting seam and felt there the whisper a bow makes before a string is drawn. She wanted to shout. She wanted to sing. She did not do either because the Dust Monks had taught her something against her will and Bee’s knots had taught her the same thing willingly. She stood and shaded her eyes and saw from the ridge the dust rise from the first bowl as if a man had thrown a blanket in anger and then shook it until he remembered blankets are for warmth. She thought, because she had not been gifted with patience the way some had been but had learned to steal it, that perhaps the bowls and the line wanted to be looms. She did not test the word aloud. She put it in her mouth like a seed.

Gavino came back at dusk with company who took up space by claiming not to. Eryn put her palms on her knees and asked them what their mothers would think if the last thing their sons did was argue with a woman about pigs on a day that had made patience an art. They bristled less at being made ridiculous than at being made ordinary. Tomas wandered up the path with a thread on his wrist and a bone in his pocket and told a long, wearying story about a man who lowered a pig into a well to see if it would come out clean and how the pig had fallen in love with the dark and refused to come back and how the man had been forced to climb down and live there and how the town had had to either bless the well or fill it and they had done neither because they’d become the sort of people who could not make a choice. It was a pointless story that was either about them or not and that annoyed them enough that they left just to spite it. Santi squeezed Tomas on the back of the neck in thanks and Tomas shrugged like a man who knows exactly what he has done.

Night broke open without theater. Under the fig-painted crenels, Sid read the day back to himself the way a man reads a recipe to see where he had lied. He and Dolores turned the tin in their hands and both thought of their mothers without saying the word, because tin remembers better than paper and both their mothers had been made to make do with it. He thought of the boy Pico asleep under a cart with one shoe half on, of Luz listening to flies decide where to land, of Lord Baeza dreaming of a wave with edges, of Sister Vero turning her mirror to face the wall, of Tenorio without his rings feeling and not liking his lightness, of Ajit with his rag around his neck snoring like a man who has earned every rasp. He thought of Eryn at the second bowl with the gray scarf tied not at her throat but round her arm and the mare’s breath close by and the black edge within reach if she allowed it and the thread in her pocket with her name on the stone.

He slept and did not dream in a way that felt like trust rather than exhaustion. The bowls hummed and then did not. The line sighed again, and two raccoons paused at the edge of it, offended, and then found another path because animals are atheists and it serves them. In the morning, when the sky decided to be a mint version of blue, Fresno woke still being Fresno instead of something else, and that counted as a victory that could not be marked on any ledger. Sid went to the rope before he went to the courthouse because he had made a law and it would be good to obey it in a visible way. He put one hand on Bee’s knot and one hand on the rope that Baeza’s men had tarred and he put his mouth close to the air over the bowl and he did not speak into it. He let it be. The hum came as if pleased.

He turned and saw Eryn below at the bend in the lower road where hawkweed grows without permission. She did not come up. She did not lift a hand. The gray scarf was around her wrist and looked, for a moment, like a ribbon Bee might have tied as a joke on the world. He went down the path until the rope asked him with its rub to stop and he did. She stood inside the little gate Marta had made like a removed piece of fence and looked, not at him, but at the slope. “I have a new word I am not ready to believe,” she said without greeting, because there are days you can only save your life by being unromantic. “I will say it when I can say it without thinking of men building churches out of it.”

“I will sit here,” Sid said, and did, in dust that had learned to be domestic. “I will tell no one your word. I will do the things I am good at doing that keep boys’ hands from empty places. I will make soup laws and breath laws and rope oaths and I will write your not-word into the part of me that makes decisions and I will obey it without speaking it.”

“Do that,” she said. “Do your little magic and I will do mine. The world likes little magics better than big ones because little magics happen while the world is looking the other way.” She almost smiled, and then the almost did the work of a whole smile simply because it had to. “When you make a bed for men to go to when they would otherwise light a fire, make it far enough from the rope that the hum has to work to reach them. Give them something to do with their hands that is not their knives. Give them the bones of goats and string and tell them to make saints out of them.
