They’ll laugh at you and then they’ll start and then they’ll keep going because they have found a thing that won’t make their friends bleed.”

“Will you come into the city,” he asked, and it was a stupid question and it was the right one because he wanted to know if his city deserved her. He wanted to know if his people could sit at a table and not try to make her name theirs.

“Not today,” she said. “There’s a boy from Piedra who thinks he can teach the hum his song. I need to sit with him and tell him he is right and then show him which part of right is safe. Also there is a man who will come with a cart and try to sell the black in the second bowl by the ounce as if it were medicine. I mean to remove his wheels. It will profit him to learn to carry what he sells.”

When he stood to go, because the rope was a beast and had pulled enough on both of them to make retreat the honorable act, he said the only one of his private sentences he would dare aloud. “When the word comes,” he told her, and his mouth made it gentle, “I will say it wrong first. That is my habit. Correct me.”

She nodded, and for a moment he saw her as a seamstress and not as a cutter of threads, as a woman who could stand at a loom and call men to bring her what they had and make from it a pattern no one had believed could be worn. Then she turned her face back to the slope and the hum, and he went up to the rope and down to the city and into the day that had already decided to be difficult without having the dignity of being dramatic.

By noon the city had learned three new ways to keep from breaking. Ajit hung buckets of water at corners that had never seen kindness and told whoever walked by that it was theirs. Sister Vero set her mirror where it would catch only the hands and not the bowl, and men came to see their hands and to discover that they did not mind them as much as they had the day before. Luz taught two women how to make the dust move on the drumskin and those women taught four and one of them named the pattern she made for a horse that had died and somehow the naming made the pattern less sad. Lord Baeza took his armor apart the rest of the way and sat in his shirt in the heat and let a child tie a ribbon around his wrist and did not remove it. Tenorio took his rings back when the shimmer failed to rise at the expected hour and put them on one by one like promises and sighed as if vows could be a relief.

In the evening the rope held a man in place who would have run to the bowl to shout a secret; he held him like a friend might hold a shirt. The man cried not because the rope denied him but because he realized he had not been listening for most of his life and that the feeling under his ribs was not one he could sell. He sat and Tomas sat with him and told him a story about a fish who had learned to climb and then had learned that the best thing about climbing was descending without shame. The story had no moral and therefore it could be kept.

On the fifth morning, which no one had pinned hopes on and therefore it permitted a little grace, the black edge in the second bowl lifted two fingers’ thickness and held without thinking better of itself. Eryn did not say her word. Sid did not go north. Ajit taught a boy to pull a chain with the right muscle. Dolores tied a knot as if the past were a thing you could make a belt from that did not rub. Lord Baeza watched a man who had decided to be better without saying it and thought, privately, that the horizon might exist even inland. Tenorio put Luz’s drumskin to his ear and hummed a note that made the dust lay in an old pattern he remembered from a quarry that had become a lake, and he cried because a man is allowed and then went on with his day. Sister Vero sat with her mirror in her lap and did not try to explain anyone to anyone.

Gavino did not come with his pigs. He sent a boy whose ear did not yet bleed. The boy left a note tied in bad twine to Marta’s brush gate that said an apology without the word and carried in it the ignorance of how to begin. Marta tucked the note into the tin and told Dolores there were worse beginnings. Sid wrote on the slate the breath schedule for the day and Ajit wrote beneath it a rude aside that made two men grin and do the work and that saved three minutes and three minutes add up over a season. Bee tied a ribbon no one saw to a place where only a woman who had loved someone slippery would look, and later that afternoon Eryn found it and laughed out loud like a girl.

When the sun laid down flat on the ridge and the bowls sang each to each in the shy talk of instruments who were just learning, the city hummed back. It was not a hymn. It was not a pledge. It was not even music as much as a refusal to be silent where silence would be taken as consent. The mourning ring received three promises and one regret. The rope held. The soup learned a new ratio of onion to salt. Men took off their rings before they got to the rope without being told. The tin held the paper through a brief wind that wanted to make men watch it rather than work and failed. And in the night, in the place where he had learned to put his want where the moon could judge it without shaming him, Sid slept with his hand open and Eryn slept with her hand in the dirt and the hum did not press harder than either could bear. It was not victory. It was what you need to keep going long enough to make victory a word you can say without the taste of blood.

At the hour when the dust turns silver and the owls yawn, King Sid of Fresno walked the eastern parapet and stared at his city like a man who had inherited a stubborn animal. The roofs were low and sun-bleached. The river beyond was stitched with irrigation lines, little veins going every direction, carrying a kingdom’s lifeblood to thirsty almonds, grapes, cotton, orchards that made a map of patience when seen from the old courthouse tower. Someone had painted royal blue along the crenels during his father’s days, and now it peeled in the shape of islands and animals. He liked to name them quietly. That one a sea horse. That one a snake with two heads. He could name everything in sight, and it still felt unnamed.

He wore a crown of hammered copper set with amber, a compromise with the land; gold was for the coast, with its salt minds and pearl brides, and Fresno was copper, good metal, honest and warmed by hands. The crown sat a little crooked on him, no matter how often Dolores the steward nudged it. He pretended not to notice. The wind brought him the scent of wet silt mixed with dry straw and diesel ghosts. The canal gates were opening, the ditchriders whistled, and the city shook itself awake.

“Majesty?” Dolores had a habit of arriving like a second thought and becoming impossible to ignore. She was narrow and solemn, all knuckle and ledger and an eye that saw through excuses like sun through thin cloth. “The Mendota siphon burned again last night.”

“Again.” Sid rested his hands on the parapet so he could feel the cool stone. “Anyone hurt?”

“A rider named Rafael. He breathed too much smoke. He’ll live if his wife can keep him from talking.”

“And the water?”

“Running, but crooked. We had to let three hours go to save the eastern fields. The figs will complain.” She glanced down into his city, where the market was unrolling like a rug and the butchers’ shade tents popped open in the pale light. “We found her mark.”

Sid didn’t ask whose. The city had learned not to say her name loudly; it made the children stare toward the river with too much story in their eyes. He nodded. “Show me.”

Dolores held up a cloth packet. Inside, a bone token, smooth with handling, etched with a lattice of fine cuts that made it glitter when the light caught it just so. A thread cut many times. People had started to call her Threadcutter. It sounded like something from old folktales you told in the heat, to make the skin go cool with dread.

“Word is,” Dolores said, “she wants a parley.”

“You believe word?” He turned the token over and over. There was a nicked corner, a little dent. He wanted to imagine her teeth there. He told himself not to.

“Word came with a man whose ear has her scar. And he came through the old fig orchard without anyone catching him. Either we are bats in daylight or we were meant not to see.”

“Meant not to see,” Sid said. The token slid lightly across his palm, alive. “We see what she wants.”

Dolores’s mouth became a string pulled tight. “You could deny her. Make a thing of it. No parley with thieves. We are a kingdom. This is not some play.”

“It is exactly some play,” he said. “And everyone knows it. And the ones who pretend not to are the worst at watching their bags.” He turned his face back to the horizon. The low ridge beyond the fields was blue in the morning, and further than that the Sierras pretended to be clouds. Once, as a boy, he had thought the mountains were people sleeping. People who could wake. “I’ll meet her.”

“With how many?” Dolores’s pencil hovered over the air, hungry for numbers.

“With whoever thinks I can survive on my wit.”

“That’s a small mess of somebodies, Majesty.”

He grinned. He didn’t do it often in council, but up here the air was unjudging. “Then I will owe you a new mess.”

Dolores bowed just enough to appease the notion of respect and left with the token caught again in her careful hands. Sid watched her go, then braced himself for the descent. The tower had steps like bad decisions, steep and spalling. He took them anyway.

The hall at the old courthouse had been cleared of its long benches decades ago to make space for maps and fishers’ nets, banners stolen from places that were not kingdoms anymore, and the throne his father had made from cherrywood and a plow blade. His father had been a man who believed you could make anything into something else if you hammered long enough. Sid had the same gift, people said, except still gentler hands. He sat, and when the guards and riders and canal men had taken their places—anywhere, there was no court ceremony for this—he lifted an arm like a man quieting a rowdy table.

“Speak,” he told Ajit, master of canals, a cheerful fellow who had a laugh like ditchwater and who smelled perpetually of minerals. Ajit was missing two fingers. He had lost them to a gate chain; he wore the loss like a medal.

“Speak? I been speaking all morning,” Ajit said. “Rosales is down there at the siphon crying like a goat and I told her I’ll give her all the rags she wants but crying won’t unburn cypress. Someone set a clean fire, majesty. And you can’t set a clean fire in damp wood unless you know the wood. She knows it. I’m telling you.” He looked around, dared a contradiction. No one offered one. “She knows our lines. She knows our nights. I ain’t saying we got a leak, but, you know—” he spread his hands the way men did when they meant everything and didn’t want to say it outright.

“Who’s on night watch at Mendota?” Sid asked.

Learning that there had been a poker game somewhere there was meant to be a man on a horse with a lamp filled the hall with a windless sort of guilt. Sid heard it hiss across teeth and thought of all the small things that made a leak a flood. “Tell Rosales to keep her rags,” he said. “And send me a few good riders who can keep quiet and ask questions looking friendly. Not noble. Friendly.”

“We ain’t noble,” Tomas—the jester, although no one in Fresno had a taste for jester hats and cornets—said from where he was sprawled on a spool of blue rope. Tomas had a way of speaking from the angle of things, like light that came in through a crack you forgot existed. “We’re parched and mean and God-chosen.”

“God is tired of being chosen,” Dolores said. “He keeps asking for receipts.”

Laughter. It loosened the air. Sid savored it. He had grown up among a people who could make jokes standing in line for water, because you had to laugh or you’d start hating the person in front of you simply because they were thirsty, too. “And the parley,” he said when the amusement had thinned to a manageable hum. “We’ll meet at the old fig orchard. I’ll take four.”

“Four?” Ajit straightened. “There’s bandit stories ripe like grapes about that orchard. They say your voice comes back to you there and tells you all the things you said wrong. It’d take twenty, to drown it out.”

“I’m counting on listening,” Sid said. “Pick the four.”

They chose them as quietly as you choose people to carry a stretcher: Vera with the lazy eye and the bad temper, a rider named Santi who had survived three winters in the foothills alone after his wife died, a young woman called Bee for the pattern of freckles on her face, and Dolores herself, because it was unthinkable for the steward to let her king go into the orchard to be unaccounted for. Ajit tried to come. Sid shook his head. “You send late water to the figs. Not too much. Enough to make them sweet, not enough to make them swell and split, so they wonder at their fortune.”

“That’s witchcraft,” Ajit said.

“It’s farming,” Sid said. “Same difference.”

He took off his copper crown, set it upon the plow throne, and put on a woven hat with a brim wide enough to shade a horse. In the mirror shards set into the pillar near the throne he saw a face he liked less and less each year: lines forming at the corners of a mouth that always tried to be kind and sometimes had to be something else, a scar on his left cheek—not a noble one; he had cut himself on a rain gate in his first summer as king. His eyes were his mother’s. Everyone told him. They told him so often he stopped knowing what his own eyes looked like to himself and only knew the story. That afternoon, he had dreamed of her hand on his crown, firm and quick, giving no time for refusal. It had happened. He had not dreamt it. He touched his temple.

They rode out in a heat that did not yet mean it but had rehearsed the lines for months. The old fig orchard crouched east of the city in a fold of land that caught fog in winter and secrets at all seasons. Half the trees were wild and half pruned, and the ones on the edges were in constant debate about which to choose. The ground was soft with dropped fruit, sour and sweet, a bargain with bees. Sid tasted one, its skin a little like paper, the inside honey-plush. He remembered a boy with his hands aluminized by moonlight, filling a bucket in the orchard and eating two figs for every one he saved. The trees had a way of leaning in to listen.

“I hear nothing yet,” Tomas murmured. He had come anyway, because he oft came and no one could recount why until he said something and then you were grateful. He wasn’t one of the four. He was the fifth that followed five steps behind and became the story people told later.

It had been agreed with whispers that there would be no archers in the trees and no horses brought into the grove. So there were archers, hidden badly enough that Sid could find them, and one horse that belonged to someone who didn’t much like rules. He saw the horse first. A pale gray mare with a black mane like spilled ink, who tossed her head in the shade, a queen tired of her crown. The man holding her rein was small and unfrightening, so he was a message. The messages mattered more than the words sometimes. Sid dismounted.

A woman stood near the largest tree. She had the casual stance of someone whose knife obeyed, and a dress that had once been a soldier’s coat cut to fit the body she had made without anyone else’s permission. In the shade her hair turned blue-black. She had wrapped a red scarf around her throat in a way that dared you to grab it and also promised to garrote you with it if you tried. He had never seen her face before. He had seen drawings of it that made legends out of cheekbones. He wished he were a poor man anywhere else.

She did not curtsy. He did not expect it. She stepped forward and offered him a fig. “We’re obliged, King,” she said. “A parley, is it? That’s the right word. We both have songs we want to sing and don’t have the right throat for.”

Sid took the fig. “If I had the right throat I could sing my song from the roof and you’d hear it in your sleep with no efforts.”

“My sleep is unruly,” she said. “It gets up and walks around. I tell it to settle down, be good, but it keeps meeting the wrong people.”

Dolores cleared her throat, which was the opposite of a song. “Be plain,” she said. “Plain saves lives.”

“Plain is ugly,” the woman said. “Plain won’t look you in the eye afterwards but does not lie about it. You want plain? I’ll give you the plain: stop locking the river like it’s a woman you stole.”

Vera murmured an apology to someone for her breath and shifted her weight. Bee sucked a seed out of her teeth and looked down. The woman in the red scarf stared only at Sid. “It is not yours,” she said, and her voice softened, so that the figs and the bees leaned in. “It isn’t anyone’s. You have built clever gates. You’re good. The men who work them are tired and proud. They deserve to be safe. But the river isn’t yours. It’s a line drawn by someone’s finger once. And the finger moved over faces that were not yet born.”

“You wear a soldier’s coat,” he said. “It belonged to someone who pointed. What’s the difference between pointing at water and pointing at a man? Both go where you want as long as you’re strong enough to make them sorry not to.”

“Ah,” she said, and smiled, and the day did a strange thing, it stepped back to make room for the smile. “That’s the thing about sorry. It curdles. It grows teeth. Down river, the earth remembers the sound too easily. The old ones say there was a time before the Breakage when men argued in rooms and signed papers and the water still went where it wanted because it had all the time in the world. We don’t have that time now. We have this season and the next, and the next might be ash.”

Sid watched the way her hands moved in the air, making and unmaking. He watched the archers who didn’t exist in the trees shift their feet. He heard his own voice the way you hear a horse’s hooves on dry clay: warning and relief. “We can talk about gates,” he said. “We can talk about schedules. We can talk about extra water for the lowest fields when the figs need it most. We cannot talk about the river being no one’s. Because if it is no one’s it becomes the strongest one’s. You know it. I know it. It’s just whether the strongest is an office with ledgers and a lock, or a man with a scarf who will leave in the night after taking everything that shines.”

“You think I take the shiny things.” The red scarf brushed her knuckles when she turned her head. “There are shinier things than copper and sugar. If I wanted all the shiny I would be in your hall counting tiles. I want a thing that can’t be counted. That’s troublesome, I know.” Her eyes flicked to the crown he was not wearing. “Do you think I like this?” She tugged the coat. “It itches. The person it fit is dead. Men died to make me a stranger to myself and now there is no road that moves in a straight line.”

“How did he die?” The question surprised him. He wanted to call it strategy and felt in his ribs that it wasn’t.

She was silent so long a fig fell and split and the scent of sugar rose like an oath. “He drowned,” she said. “Near Firebaugh. He was pulled under by a snag of manzanita that everyone ignored because we all thought we knew the river better than we did. He went down believing in his own lungs. He came up too slow to do anything but show me his eyes. If I cut a thread now and then, know that he went down with all the threads in his hands, and I still am not sure if he meant to give them away or keep them.”

Sid held the fig she had handed him and did not eat it. Flies touched the bruises on its skin. “I’m sorry,” he said, and did not try to make it a king’s sorry that could right the world with a decree. “We can walk out there and cut the manzanita together.”

“Your gates,” she said, and her tone became a thing made of rocks. “They are manzanita.”

“Not all of them.”

“Enough.”

“Tell me your name,” he said. “You know mine in a hundred stories. Let me have one word to say that means you and not the idea of you.”

“If I give you my name,” she said softly, “you’ll keep it in your pocket and take it out when you’re alone and hold it and it will grow warm and heavy and you’ll know all its edges, and then when you’re too far from me and you want to be close, you’ll say it to yourself and that will be a kind of theft.”

“I’ll find that edge no matter what you say,” he said, and realized he had moved a little closer, and that everyone in both parties had noticed and not decided yet if it was dangerous.

“Eryn,” she said finally. “My name is Eryn Vale. And I would rather be a seamstress than a cutter of threads but you cannot stitch with gates.”

“Eryn,” he said, and he did feel it, the weight. He felt the way the syllables sat on the tongue like a fruit pit, something that might grow if planted and might just choke you if you mis-swam. “I’m Sid.” He almost said, I am Sid of Fresno, or King Sid, or any of the names that were less like him and more like duties. He didn’t. “Come walk,” he said. “No one will shoot if you don’t. I don’t shoot. Ask anyone. I’m famous for it.”

“I know what you’re famous for,” she said dryly. But she walked, and they walked under the low branches, where the sun made little coins of light on the old grass. The others trailed at a careful distance, their footfalls different languages.

“Your men set a clean fire,” he said, while a fly made its mind up about his hat brim. It was too blunt a thing to say. He said it anyway. “That was careful. It was also cruel.”

“I know the taste of careful,” she said. “Cruel lives next door. You keep telling yourself you only visit. The first night you sleep on that couch because you’re tired. The second because it’s easier to not go home in the dark. People make a nest in your hair. They tell you you look like you belong. You forget the way the sheets smell in the place where you said you would always lay your head.” Her hand brushed his sleeve. He told himself she had done it to keep moving.

“Is there a way we can make new maps?” he asked. “Maps where a little is given without being stolen?”

“You want a treaty,” she said. “On paper. With your stamp. With a witness. With Tomas to make a joke at the end that people will call wisdom if they like you and bad manners if they don’t.”

“Tomas is not wise,” he said.

“I am exactly wise enough,” Tomas called from a branch he should not have been able to climb as quietly as he had. “Which is less than a god and more than a guard, and in the middle of everything stupid.”

Eryn looked up at him and laughed in a way that made Vera relax for the first time all morning. “Hello, fool,” she said. “Do you remember me?”

“We all remember the stories we tell ourselves to live,” Tomas replied, and plucked a fig and missed his mouth and dropped it on his shoe. “But not the ones we tell ourselves to die.”

Sid didn’t know what to do with half the things Tomas said, not because he was a fool but because he was a mirror that refused to reflect anything but the person looking. “If you could make a treaty,” Sid said, “what would it ask for?”

“Dignity,” she said with no flair at all. “And a year. One year where you don’t let a single acre rot because the wrong men were late. One year where no one’s child walks seven miles for a bucket you’ll sell back to them at a price you won’t pay yourself. One year to see if I can stop cutting threads because there’s nothing left to strangle anyone.”

“I can give you a year we both promise to be good,” he said. “But being good is an agreement with a ghost. As soon as the water is low and the wind runs hard and the canals crack, men will feel old hunger. What then?”

“Then,” she said, and leaned in as if she were telling him how to cheat at dice, “you remember that there was a year you did not.” She tilted her head. “Do you know how soft the river smells after the first rain? The dust lifts like a child to be held and then it falls down slow and you can taste a metal thing, and the worms come up, curious and brave, like men who have never had their hearts broken.”

He saw it behind his eyes and, worse, in his chest. “I know,” he said.

“Then you know why I’m in your orchard saying too much.” She straightened as if shaking off a hand. “I am making a mistake here. I should be making a point with my elbow and my men’s sharpness. And yet.” She shrugged. “Here we are.”

“We are,” he said, and he could feel the long afternoon ahead of him in which he would be unable to do any of the small useful things that kept the panic of being a king at bay. “We are. Will you eat with me?”

“In your hall? No,” she said. “Everyone will know and everyone will stare. They will watch your mouth to see what you choose to taste.” She glanced toward the city as if to prove she could see it even through the trees. “You can eat with me. Where I sleep is nobody’s idea of safe.”

“Where do you sleep?” He wanted to put himself in every place she said. He wanted to parcel himself into invisible pieces and hide them in the grasses and in the gorge and under the bark of the figs so he would always be with her and always know how to get back. The wanting made him ridiculous to himself. He forgave himself for it and it did not go away.

“In a circle of ruin downriver,” she said. “At night the old concrete walls sweat and the coyotes laugh at nothing. I will not tell you which circle. Not yet, Sid. Do not pretend to be shocked by not yet.”

“I would not dare,” he said. “I have done not yet so often I thought it was a town I owned.”

He did not kiss her. It was barely possible, for a heartbeat, if the bees had all decided to go quiet at once and the archers had all sneezed from fig dust and the wind had stopped to tell them, the two of them just under the branch that held Tomas up like a bad idea in a good place. He did not. He thinks he didn’t. Memory is a wayward dog.

They brought no treaty home, and if anyone had asked Sid what he had brought instead he would have held his hands apart and said the weight between them was not air and not good sense and not a lie. He ate fig jam on stale bread in the late afternoon with Ajit and listened to the man talk about gates like lovers. He half-slept in his chair and saw a river that had a mouth and spoke. He saw his father up to his knees in water cursing the things he loved for not being easier.

That night, under an angry moon that had somewhere else to be, a boy named Diego ran the south road with a story. He ran as fast as a story deserves. The guards at the tower took him in with a cup of something too weak to call coffee and stood him in front of the king who had put his crown on again because people were watching and watched him because he looked like a boy who might be the first page of a bad chapter.

“Majesty,” the boy said, and then remembered to bow, and did so while still talking. “There’s a shepherd in the foothills who saw fire walking like an animal.”

“People get drunk,” Ajit said mildly from somewhere. “And the imagination is a—”

“No. He was not drunk. We have no liquor left. His dog is burnt. He brought the paw. He wouldn’t come in the city because he says he doesn’t be in rooms, but he gave me the paw. He said tell the king the mountain has a tooth. He said words I didn’t understand about rattling stone. He knows rocks, he’s a man who knows rocks in his hands, and he said they were humming like someone breathing bad.”

Tomas sat up straighter as if the floor had nudged him. “Humming,” he said, and the word fell into the open place that had just formed in the hall. “Is that the word he used? He’s a shepherd. Did he say humming. Or did he say singing.”

“Humming,” Diego said. “But it got in his bones, he said, and then went away and took his breath. He wants his dog to be seen by a priest so whoever did this knows God saw it too. Please don’t make me say it again. I ran."

Dolores took the paw with both hands like a sacrament and did not flinch. The pad was black and bubbled. Sid closed his eyes and saw flame organized into a body. He opened them and saw his people organized into hope. “Find the shepherd,” he said. “Bring him a woman who knows herbs and a man who knows rocks and someone who knows how to listen to men who have lived too long with sheep.” He could feel around his words something too old for his throat. “And send word up the old road. Ask it everything it knows.”

“Majesty,” Dolores said later, when the hall had emptied down to the skins of its conversations and only the work of tomorrow remained. “If there is fire walking—”

“There isn’t,” he said. “Not yet. There is someone who saw too much of a thing he cannot name, and we will name it for him and then it will sit down. It will become a story with a beginning, and then it will be manageable.”

“Stories have middles.” She rubbed her forehead with two dirty fingers. “We forget that. We always forget the middle is swamp.”

He wanted to tell her Eryn’s name and didn’t. It sat whole in his mouth and made everything else taste like it. He went to his room and took off his crown and placed it on the window where the moon could see it and judge him. Down in the yard someone sang a song about men who choose the wrong women and then forgive them, which is to say, men who choose. The city’s heat moved around him like a creature who did not mean to love him and did anyway, clumsily.

In the morning he went out with no guards and no crown. He went to the canal where the siphon had burned clean. He wanted to see the way the ash had organized itself when it fell. He wanted black on his hands as if touching what hurt in person made it less likely to happen again somewhere he could not reach. Rosales found him there. She was a short woman with shoulders like a yoke and a voice like a whistle. She called him King and then told him a story about her grandmother that had nothing to do with anything. He realized after that it had everything to do with everything. People loved by telling you what they could not hold anymore, because it spilled.

“She left me her knife,” Rosales said at the end, and showed him. The blade was old and new. Someone had ground it on new stone. It had a little nick.

He took it and it fit his hand as if he had held it before. “Do you want it back?” he asked.

“If you keep it,” she said, “you keep her. And then she’ll get you killed, and I will have to mourn twice. Give it to someone else who needs to pretend the past’t steel.”

“Is that me?”

“It might be. My grandmother would spit and say it’s everyone.” Rosales took off her hat and wiped her hair back. “You got a look, King. Like you saw a puddle that has sky in it and you jumped. Be careful, yes? That sky will drown you as quick as water.”

“I’ll practice holding my breath,” he said, and then, because it was a morning for not yet, he closed his eyes and pictured Eryn catching a fig in one hand, her head thrown back when Tomas had said something only half was joke. He saw the red scarf like a wound and like a warning and like something you tied around a gift so that even if you were all elbows and wrong words the recipient would know you had tried to be splendid.

He returned to the hall. Papers waited with the patience of things that could outlive kings. He signed his name on water schedules and confirmed a levy on pistachios and allowed the songs of three old men who claimed to be the same man to be sung at market on Wednesdays. He corrected a scribe’s spelling. He forgot what the old spelling had been. Night came and he did not ask Dolores to read back to him the day’s mercies and crimes because he didn’t think he could give each of them the same mouth.

In the solitude between lamps, someone came to his window. For a breath he thought the river had stood up and learned to climb. He reached for Rosales’s knife and felt it in his hand like an answer to a question he was not done asking. A shadow detached itself from the shadow and sat on his sill as if it had every right and no shoes. Eryn. She had a way of changing the size of the room.

“This is idiotic,” she said without greeting. “I could be anyone. You could have shot me.”

“I don’t shoot,” he said. He stood and he was not surprised at all at how necessary it felt to be standing while she sat. “How. Why.”

“Because I realized after I left,” she said, looking at his crown on the sill as if it were a small animal she might feed or not, who could say, “that if I let your people tell you about the thing up in the foothills they’d clean it up so you would be able to sleep. And I wanted to see your face when you didn’t. You make a particular face when you have one ache too many. It is not a king’s face. It is a person’s. You should be careful. It’ll get you loved in the wrong ways.”

“The dragon,” he said.

Her eyes, which had seemed to him like a lake at dusk, widened and lost everything but the reflection of his mouth. “You say it like it exists.”

“You came here to say it.”

“I came here to not say it.” She leaned back against the frame. Her scarf had no red tonight. It was gray as the mare she had brought to the orchard, and that felt like a kind of sacrament, too. “There’s a pit up there. Or a bowl. Or a wound. And at the bottom of it something breathed and the rocks hummed, and a shepherd’s dog got burned not by flame but by a sound. That’s what the man said. He said his dog lay down because it thought it was night and the night made his hair go away. I saw the circle from far. I saw birds rise at wrong hours. I thought. Eryn, you need to be quiet. Your whole life you have been loud because that felt like the only way to exist. And now, hush, be small. But then I remembered you and how you said you know the smell of the earth when it lifts. And I did something stupid. I came.”

He moved towards her because there was nothing else to do with his body. “If there is a dragon—”

“Stop,” she said. “Don’t educate it with your mouth.”

“If there is,” he said anyway, “everything else we are arguing about is stubbornness at the wrong scale. We need to stop being clever with gates and be clever with worship.”

“We are not going to worship a thing that burns dogs with sound.” She turned to the night where the city lay, pretending to be a map and failing at it, badly. “We are going to make sure we live to fight our small war another day.”

“Are we fighting?” he asked.

She looked at him then, and he saw that her face could become lovely with cruelty or with joy and he would be unable to tell which would break him more. “We don’t know how to do anything else,” she said, and reached for his crown and tipped it off the sill. He lunged, caught it. She laughed, because she had known he would and because it was very funny that a man who might have to become a myth had the hands of a ditchman. “Don’t start,” she said. “Don’t make in your heart a room for me yet. I am full of splinters.”

“I have rooms full of splinters,” he said, and it sounded ridiculous when he said it and truer than anything else he had said that week. He set the crown down on the floor, where it made a ring of copper moonlight. “Stay,” he said. It was not wise. It wasn’t even cunning. It was a request from a kind of animal older than kingdoms.

She stood up on the sill without taking his hand. “I’ve already stayed too long. You have someone named Dolores who did not scream from a fig tree but will scream soon. She will tell you there’s a man in the yard with a burned paw and a song about stone, and you will look at me and you’ll want to ask me what to do. Don’t. Decide with your people. When you need a person who knows how to not die when rocks sing, send a ribbon down the old canal tied in a knot I recognize. Don’t write. Paper is greedy.”

“You are,” he said, wanting to stop her without wanting to be a person who stopped things that moved fast. He didn’t know what he intended to put after the words. He never did, and that was why he was always slightly behind everything he loved.

“I’m not your enemy in the way your men want,” she said, and then was nothing but shadow again. “I’m worse,” she said from down in the yard, and then there was only the night, which had, at last, settled down.

Dolores did scream. Not like a goat; like a woman whose ledgers had burst into flame. Sid went to the window for the second time that night and looked out over Fresno, his, and imagined the mountains as sleeping people and tried to imagine what face they would make if they woke and had no names left. He thought about his father’s hands and his mother’s eyes and Tomas in trees and Ajit loving his gates and Rosales’s knife and Rosales’s grandmother. He thought about Eryn’s mouth shaping his name as if she were sewing with it.

When the messenger ran through the gate and fell, Sid already had his boots on and his mouth set in the only line he knew for certain the city understood: we will go see. He went down, and out, and into his future like you go into a river you grew up beside: thinking you know it and knowing you might not, and going anyway, because you are from here. He was from Fresno. He was king. And he was a man who would, soon, learn the shape of dragons in his teeth and who else’s name they could keep.

Dolores’s scream was not panic; it was a flare sent up so the necessary would gather. The yard below the window filled the way a cup fills when a heavy hand pours—quickly and without apology. The boy who had run the story lay on his side, chest jumping like a fish netted and unsure of mercy. The shepherd stood apart from him, as men do who have spent too long with animals and wind. He held his hat in both hands as if he had come to a church he did not recognize but knew he should respect. Beside him, on a cloth that had held oranges once, lay the blackened paw. It was a thing that should not have been severed from anything, and yet it had been presented like a proof to a world that no longer believed without them.

“Name,” Dolores said, because names let you hold people steady.

“Mateo,” the shepherd answered, the lint at the edge of his cuffs smoked down to nothing. “Mateo of Dry Creek, the real Dry Creek, not that ditch you all call a creek to feel better. I kept my dog from whimpering for two hours and then he did not keep.” He lifted his chin toward the foothills as if they were a person who had wronged him and did not yet know it. “I have slept under oak that crackled with lightning and not broken. This is not that. The stones are behaving badly. It is a thing no one taught them and yet they learned. It went in my teeth. The old ones say the bones sing when the end comes. I am not old and I am telling you my bones sang.”

Ajit came up behind Sid and stood a respectful half foot back the way men do when they want to catch a king if he falls but not crowd him into proving he won’t. “Humming in stone is not a ditchman’s language,” he murmured, more to the air than anyone. “It is a quarryword. We could ask old Tenorio. He listens to rocks like they whisper gossip.”

“We will ask everyone,” Sid said. He stepped down into the yard, felt the looseness of sand under his boots, the easy bite of grit. He knelt by the cloth with the black paw and said a word he had never liked saying out loud because it was too simple to fit the sort of grief that came with it. “Sorry.”

Mateo stared at him as if he were a trespasser he might forgive on principle but not in practice. “Sorry is cloth you hold to a wound so your hand has something to do,” he said. “It doesn’t stop the blood. Your men think the mountain is a drunk husband who will sleep it off. I am telling you it has a tooth and it is waking teeth first.”

“We go,” Sid said, and before Dolores could remind him which signatures would be late, which men would take advantage, which gates would sit untended enough to tempt mischief, he raised his hands and shaped the morning as best he could. “Ajit stays and makes a map that counts men as well as gates. Send Rosales to the south siphon with two who can say no without shouting. Find Tenorio. Send word to the outposts that no one goes alone into circles or bowls or old quarries. Pair shepherds. Pair children. Pair anyone with feet. Dolores, count rope and lantern oil, and pull my riding coat that does not say King in every stitch. Bring the water skins that do not leak when a person wishes them to.”

“All water skins leak when you are tired,” Dolores said, but she was already leafing through her mental ledgers and nodding to people who did not know that nod meant they were now part of the chapter they would retell to grandchildren. “Vera is with a toothache. We take Bee. We take Santi. We take Tomas whether we choose to or not. And we take Marta.”

“Which Marta,” Tomas asked from the edge of the ladder, where he had been listening with his head upside down as if the blood gathered there would make a better mind. “Because if you mean Marta of the yard, she is pregnant with a sadness and should not go near anything that hums. If you mean Marta of Piedra, she will spit and come and make the rocks behave by telling them her mother’s stories until they feel foolish.”

“Piedra,” Dolores said, and Tomas saluted nothing in particular and veered off like a kite freed from a wise child’s fingers.

Tenorio arrived as if summoned by consideration alone, an old man with calves like oaks and hands that had not known softness since his own mother’s palm when he was a boy. He wore a string of tiny fossils around his neck the way priests wear bones. His hearing had gone in one ear and so he turned the good one toward Sid with a theatricality that made Bee hide a smile. “The earth makes music whether you listen or not,” he announced without being asked anything. “Mostly it’s a lullaby if you mind your feet. Sometimes it is a wedding song, you can tell because everything shakes in a way that makes people want to dance even if their knees were at war with them yesterday. You say it hummed.” He looked down at the paw and made an old man’s cross over his chest in a way that made Sid feel young and unwell. “We will hear if it wants us to.”

They left the city by the east gate so that Fresno could watch them go and adjust its opinion of itself accordingly. People see kings leave and become either brave or foolish; Sid preferred brave and suspected most days that what he got was a braid of both. The road out was a two-lane memory where the asphalt sloughed like old skin, patched with gravel and volunteer grass that made the horses pay attention. The canals followed for a while like faithful dogs and then wandered off to flirt with fields, to promise and deliver and sometimes only promise. You could tell where the lines had been long before men put water in them by the way the land settled in upon itself, making gentler curves, a body remembering where it liked to be touched.

The foothills gathered long and blue-green, oak standing in their toadstool shade, granite showing itself in the honest way rock does when there is nothing left between it and sky. The heat had taken to itself a vocabulary—cicada and dust and the kind of silence that isn’t empty but is full of waiting. Santi rode as if the horse and his own bones were in a marriage that had shed its performative tenderness in favor of competence. Bee counted hawks and kept count out loud after the third because it was a comfort humans invented to keep from feeling as small as they were. Dolores balanced a ledger on her knee until the horse told her with a toss that she would regret it, and she put it away with a sigh that had arithmetic in it anyway.

“Say it again,” Tenorio asked Mateo, who had come despite his eyes being hollowed by losing his dog. “Rattling stone. Humming. Breathing that had words in it or that was just air being unshy.”

Mateo spat neatly in a way that managed not to offend anyone’s gods. “It got into my hat. It made my belt hit my hip like a hammer. It made the sheep put their faces down and pretend they could go back into the earth like acorns. It was not wind. It was not the thing you feel when a truck goes by. It had direction. It came from a bowl and went in my teeth and then it left and all the birds were confused about the hour and sang the wrong songs.”

“Wrong songs,” Tomas said. He was on foot, because he liked to feel the pattern of the world with his ankles, as if his body could read the same text the land had always been writing. “Fools know wrong songs. They are like a joke that doesn’t want to be funny and still is, because the person telling it is trying so hard not to think about their mother.”

Santi flicked a look at him that might have become a grin if the day were softer. “Do you plan to make sense today.”

“I plan to provide commentary,” Tomas said. “Sense is a trick gods used to sell men fear.”

They left behind the last almond rows where white shells had made a brief spring snow and turned into a kind of country that liked to pretend it was untouchable and then turned its ankle on a gopher hole. The oaks offered shade like a grandfather who wanted you to sit in it and tell him what you thought you knew so he could take it apart gently and give you new pieces. As they climbed, the river—no longer neatly canal—offered itself in glimpses of polish and tumble. Sid could smell it even when he could not see it, the way the nose remembers a friend on the day you mean to be dignified and are not. He nodded to the water because he had learned as a boy that talking out loud to things made your own bones listen.

The first hint of the bowl was not its shape but a quiet. It was not absence of sound so much as a shivering off of everything that could be called song. Cicadas went to ground. Flies forgot their history. The horses’ ears tried to be useful and failed. After that came something like the note of a big bell rung in another valley, arriving disheveled and late, and then the taste—metal, yes, but also something old that had been asleep under everything and was now adjusting to the idea that everything had been built without its consent.

They came over the lip and the circle lay below, shoulder-high to a giant, glassed in places as if some lunatic had taken an iron and smoothed the land. Dark stones gleamed like scales that had learned restraint. In the center, a depression glowed not with light but with attention. It drew the eye the way a hole in a story does. Around the edge, where the grasses had done their best to have dignity and failed, a pattern of ripple and furrow marked where sound had behaved like water. Sid wanted to kneel. He wanted to plant his palm flat on the dirt and ask so many questions that for a moment he could not think of one worth starting with.

“Do not speak,” Tenorio said, and brought up a hand in a gesture so delicate it felt liturgical. “The earth is tuning. You wait to hear if you are wanted. Think about babies. Babies know when their crying is useful. We will be babies now and hold still like fools holding their breath.”

Bee put her hand on her own throat as if to keep something in. Dolores folded her ledger against her chest and tried to look like a person who believed her columns would still matter in an hour. Santi closed his eyes and let the horse find balance without his help, because he had a faith in animal sense that had come from living through winter when winter meant weeks of listening to your own blood. Tomas climbed the lowest limb of an oak that leaned toward the bowl and lay along it like a thought that might be comfort if you spoke it right.

The hum came as a nothing that arranged dust. It made the hairs on Sid’s arm decide to be trees in a wind. He felt it under his tongue, a new flavor, the way mint can surprise you in a stew and you cannot decide if you like the cook any better for it. The depression changed, slightly, the way a sleeping chest moves when the body underneath decides a deeper breath would help. A slow spill of small stones slid toward the center and then stopped, a minute failure that felt like mercy. The horses stamped. Mateo’s hat brim trembled as if a tiny hand had flicked it and then was ashamed of the flick.

“We are too close for ignorance and too far for courage,” Dolores said, and the words were small and square and necessary.

“Take off your metal,” Tenorio instructed, as if he were telling children to take off shoes before stepping onto a clean floor. “Coins. Buckles. Not all of it. We are not pagans at a cousin’s wedding. But the things that wish to sing with whatever this is, let them be silent. I have seen a man’s tooth ring in his skull for a day after lightning made a point and he remained unconvinced. We don’t argue with it. We say, excuse me, a chair for the elder.”

They did as they were told in a way that might have been funny anywhere else. Kings unbuckling. Stewards loosening buttons with elaborate dissatisfaction. Fool plucking trinkets from his pockets as if they were rabbits who refused to winter. Sid took off Rosales’s knife and held it for a long breath that felt like confession. He held it to his forehead and put it in the dust. He crouched and touched the ground with three fingers—his father’s superstition inherited without understanding—and then let his hand flatten.

Heat came through in a sheet that did not obey what he knew of heat. It did not scorch. It informed. He felt told. He felt like a boy sent from the table to wash his hands better. He had a violent, disorienting urge to apologize out loud to the land for every ledger, every gate, every clever well-timed release, every pride that had been dressed as planning. He swallowed and planted his hand harder as if pressure would make a different virtue.

“Does it have a mouth,” Bee whispered after the hum sagged into ordinary air again, then rose and then sagged, as if breathing had not yet become habit.

“If it does,” Tomas said from his tree, “we should be careful not to teach it how to kiss.”

“See there,” Santi said, because there are always men who will point when a thing is too big for speech. On the far side of the depression, where the glassed soil met pale dust, a shape long and curved lay half-buried. It could have been a log, except it had the kind of geometry that logs don’t learn. It had edges that remembered heat and had decided against it. It was dark like cooled forge. When the next hum lifted and the dust swam, the curve showed an under-pattern, lines like the maps the city kept, everything taking a place, and Sid had to press his hand to his mouth to not say the word he and Eryn had agreed not to teach the air.

“We will not take steps toward it,” Tenorio said. “We will not throw stones into this bowl as if we are children proving we exist by making ripples in another person’s bath. The thing is older than our shouting. We will learn how to stand in the presence of it without breaking our own ankles.”

“People are going to come here anyway,” Dolores said. “The ones who think being first is a religion. The ones who think being right is. The ones who sell water in small cups.”

“I will post men on the road,” Sid said. He could feel how thin authority might become around a hole in the world. “We will make a circle around the circle and ask people to wait until we have a law that fits this. We will make a better law even if it must be uglier. We will tell them it hums in teeth and that should frighten anyone who uses theirs to chew their pride.”

“That will work for an hour,” Bee said. “Not longer. We should talk fast inside that hour.”

“The shepherds will listen,” Mateo said. “Not because of you. Because we are not eager to be rearranged. Tell the orchard men that this will make bees forget their beds. That will sober them. Tell the women who keep the graves that the earth here wants to talk too loudly over them and their dead will not hear properly. That will fetch their attention.”

“Tell the boys there might be a thing that breathes fire and then tell them the fire burns with sound,” Tomas added. “They won’t know what that means and that mystery will keep them cautious for some portion of a week.”

“Get me a ribbon,” Sid said. He felt foolish immediately and leaned into the foolishness because sometimes you had to cross a thing to make it a bridge. “And get me someone’s hands who know knots like language.”

Bee had already pulled a scrap from the hem of her shirt, the piece she’d torn off that morning to make a band for her braid. It was yellow with a faded line of blue that once might have been flowers and now was a suggestion. She frowned at it as if it had to be argued with, then set it between her teeth and freed her hands. “What knot do you want,” she asked around the fabric.

“The one a person who isn’t invited recognizes from across a lot of rough water,” Tomas said before Sid could admit he did not know. “The one that says, I am acting wrong in order to do a right thing.”

Bee worked as if she had always known the right kind of wrong. Her fingers twisted and un-twisted. The ribbon became something that was not a bow and not a noose but a message in the shape of caution. She taught the knot to itself twice until it agreed to hold in both directions, then slipped it over Sid’s fingers to feel how it lay. “You put it on the old canal,” she said. “Not where people look. Where a person who had to leave once might look when they were choosing whether to be brave again or leave again.”

“We do not leave this thing to bandits,” Dolores said. “I don’t care if they wear red scarves or the bones of saints. We keep it in the ledgers if we can and in our mouths if we must.”

“I am keeping it in my vocabulary until it changes me,” Sid said. He could feel the shape of the day already choosing him and could not decide if he was relieved or afraid. “Tenorio, if it hums again, tell me whether it asks us to stay or go.”

“It’s a bowl and a wound,” Tenorio said. “Wounds ask you to clean them and then to leave them alone. Bowls ask to be filled. We will find out which one is hungrier.”

They drew back to the shade, not out of cowardice but because standing in sun with no plan makes men make bad ones. Marta of Piedra came up the road as if she had sworn the foothills to different manners and they had agreed to humor her. She was a woman with forearms like mortars and a mouth that chewed seeds a lot of the time she wasn’t chewing foolishness. She spat and looked down and chewed again and spat. “This is not mine,” she said with the kind of authority that made everyone want to give it to her anyway. “It’s not any mason’s. The lines at the edge are not from drowning in rain. I don’t like it. When I don’t like a thing it means men will run toward it because they want to prove me wrong.”

“You can taste it,” Tomas suggested. “Taste tells a fool what to do when his head is full of fathers.”

Marta crouched. She dipped two fingers in dust and touched them to her tongue. She didn’t wince the way Sid wanted her to. She frowned, which was worse. “There’s quarry in it. And kiln. And a little bit of burnt bird. And a flavor I don’t have a word for, which makes me dislike my mother because she did not give it to me.” She stood and wiped her hands on her skirt, then kicked the ground the way you kick a door to make certain a friend hears you coming. “If the stones start moving, we get everyone on the downhill side of trees. The trees will catch what they can’t understand.”

Sid sent Santi and Bee back down the road with instructions like pieces of honeycomb—sweet enough to carry with complaint built in. Stop at the upper pump and tell them no one draws extra. Stop at Rosales’s cousin’s place and tell him to tether his pigs under the oak, not the fig. I know pigs do as they please but make them please me. Bee, tie this to the old canal at the turn where the dirt has learned to lie. If a woman with a scarf comes, tell her to take off her scarf and wait where the fancy manzanita droops like the beard of a saint who has lost his humor. Do not say her name.

“Do not say her name like she’s a curse,” Bee said. She tied the ribbon into the loop of her belt like a promise. “Names are only curses if you speak them with bad intentions.”

“Or with longing,” Tomas added. “Longing can ruin even a poem.”

“I will ruin no poems,” Bee said, and left with Santi, who had a way of making the space around him feel durable that made gods forgive him the things he did not believe.

The circle’s hum settled to a memory under noon. Heat took over as the main authority. Tenorio sat with his hands on his knees and his head tipped and told Sid stories about the times he had seen earth do something unusual and it had turned out to be small men with large ideas, and then the times he had seen it and it had turned out to be the opposite. Marta muttered to the stones as if complimenting them into complacency. Mateo stood always as if he were about to leave, a man whose home had been burnt out of him and knew it and was honest about the draft.

Sid slept badly and briefly, chin on chest, and woke because the air had shifted. It had picked up the smell rain has when it is only a rumor and will stay that way to punish you. The hum came again, lower this time, as if the thing in the bowl had found a different part of its chest with which to think. Birds rose from the oaks on the far ridge all at once as if they had been told a cruel joke. When the hum sank, dust did not. It hung in little columns, then fell as if someone had remembered gravity late.

“Men,” Dolores said in the voice she used for lists when she could not bear to write them down. “We cannot own this. We can argue with it and make ourselves tired. Or we can help the ones who will be hurt when other men argue with it. I have four carts I can empty by nightfall of wheat we can spare. I will send them to the women in Lower Woodlake because their fences are already failing and whatever this is will make men less generous even if it never opens its eyes.”

“This is what it is to be steward,” Tenorio said. “You count hunger and how it moves and you move faster. You do not make speeches about the way the earth smells.”

“I can do many things at once,” Dolores said. “I am a woman and I am tired, so it comes naturally.”

When Bee and Santi came back by the lower road, dust to their knees, the knot was gone from Bee’s belt and there was a new shadow in the company of their horses that had not yet decided whether it wanted to be a person or an idea. Eryn walked a pace behind them as if she had been there all along and only now felt like being seen. She had wrapped her hair under a gray cloth and left her throat bare, which felt like a trick until you realized it was also a kind of kindness, because it did not dare you to reach for the scarf that was not there. Her eyes came first and then the rest.

“I tied it as if I loved you,” Bee said to Sid about the ribbon, then to Eryn because she had enough air for two honesties. “And you came as if you loved him.”

Eryn gave Bee a look that had salt in it and otherwise declined to answer the thing that would have made everything small. She took in the bowl, the people, the way the wind had decided to be a dog and lie down in the shade of the oaks, the men in it, the fear trying hard not to be called that. Her mouth flattened. “I did not put my scarf on because I knew you would think to tie the ribbon and I knew I would make a poor entrance if I had to take it off in front of your men.”

“You would never make a poor entrance,” Tomas said. “Even if you came in on your knees dragging a sack of bad fish.”

“I have done that,” Eryn said. “It worked. People were too busy smelling me to look to their coin. What is this.” She didn’t put we into it. She wasn’t a fool.

“A bowl and a wound,” Tenorio said. He rose the way old men do when they are called into being by curiosity and politeness at once. “We are deciding which is hungrier.”

Eryn took a step forward as if she had felt the hum under her feet before she heard it. She stopped when it rose and you could see in the set of her body that she knew something about the way you held yourself when sound wanted to push your bones around. Her eyebrows winged up, not with fear, but recognition. “I have heard a church like this,” she said softly. “Far south. The stones had a music when you pressed your ear against them. A woman there told me that everything hums if you love it long enough.”

“If this wants love the way it hums,” Dolores said, “then I don’t wish to know the word for its hate.”

Eryn’s gaze moved to Sid and skipped his crown as if it were not there, which it was not, and landed on his mouth. He felt himself become the wrong kind of visible. “Do not say the word we both didn’t,” she warned. “I can feel you readying it like a spoon. Don’t feed it your certainty.”

“I am not certain of anything,” he said. “We are only a crowd of different fears around a hole.”

“Good,” she said, and went to the lip the way a person goes to a dock at night to throw stolen bread to fish because it feels like priesting even if God would quibble about the details. She knelt and placed her hand on the glassed earth and closed her eyes. For a horrible moment Sid imagined the hum rising and taking her skin the way fire takes hair and he put his hand on the knife he had removed and found himself with nothing to hold. The hum did rise. She flinched. She did not move away. When it sank, she took her hand back and the part of her palm that had touched the ground shone faintly as if she’d pressed it into a coin.

“That is not only heat,” she said. “It is a thing I do not have words for, which makes me hungry. You can feel it asking. The way a place that’s about to become a town asks men to name their streets before anyone has built a house. It wants to be called. It wants to stop being a thing that only happens and be a thing that is.”

“What happens when you name a thing like this,” Marta asked. “Carts roll in and men argue about who will pay for the stones. Then a man like me is asked to mark it so that when it tears it will tear along the line they thought they wanted.”

Eryn looked up at the oak where Tomas lounged. “Sing something,” she demanded. “Nothing clever. A work song. A woman washing a shirt. A child being told to sleep. I want to hear the way it moves against the hum.”

Tomas glowered like a cat given a bath and then sang. He didn’t have a voice you would put on a square for coins. He had a voice that sounded like rope, notched and trustworthy. He sang a line his mother had sung about soap you make when you are poor and happy with your poverty, and a line his father had sung about mules and bad deals and the way the sky takes the heat and does not return it as a favor, and a line he had made up about his own mouth. The hum threaded through it like a second singer who refused to harmonize and still could not be said to be out of tune. Dust lifted in thin prayer flags. A lizard ran slower than it wished to and then remembered what running was and sped.

“We can get out of this alive,” Eryn said, and it was the first generous thing she’d said all day. “But it will tilt everything. The men who want to own it will come. The poets will too, and they are sometimes worse. The women with babies will wonder if the babies’ sleep will change and if it does they will blame and forgive the wrong people for a while. You need to make a law that is an apology and a dare at once.”

“I can write a law that stumbles toward that,” Dolores said. “But it will last as long as you and your hum behave. We need something that stands when flour is scarce and when there is too much flour and men grow greedy with bread.”

“You will write something that says no fires within two fields,” Tenorio said, turning the world into the language he trusted. “You will write something that says no digging here unless a woman who has put her ear to stones says yes. You will send boys up the old road to stop pilgrims from throwing bottles that break into knives.”

“And you will send word to the coastal kings,” Ajit’s voice said from behind them, and they all turned, because he had said he would stay and in that way men remind you that promises are elastic when true fear stretches them. He looked embarrassed and not sorry. “I cannot fix a gate if half the men who know the counterweights have gone up into the hills to see a thing that hums. I will send boys if you cannot send men. And you will tell the people by the salt that we are not hoarding a miracle.”

“We are not calling it that,” Sid said. “We are calling it a problem that requires singing and rope.”

“You will call it whatever you like at the courthouse,” Ajit said, arms folded, two missing fingers curled toward his palm as if they were listening still. “In the market it will be miracle even if it eats a goat for breakfast. We can manage gates. We can’t manage mouths. But we tell them a thing loud and often and some of them will pretend to believe it for a while.”

The afternoon laid its weight on them like a polite aunt who means to smother. A wind came up and set the oak leaves speaking in their dry consonants. From down the hill a thin river of people began to arrive, the curious and the careful and the ones who had been told to stand here and not there and were midway through deciding what they thought about being told in general. Sid found himself standing always half between the bowl and the people, as if the middle position could translate anything into kindness. He let the pattern of the work take him. Answer a question. Detour a boy who wanted to throw a rock, away not only from the bowl but from the future he would make for himself if no one taught him how not to enjoy breaking. Let an old woman with a needle-box touch his sleeve until she remembered why she’d come. Ask Mateo if he wanted to walk or sit. Send Bee to the canal with the ribbon because even if Eryn stood here now you had to honor the version of her that had not known if she would choose to.

By sunset the circle had not opened and the hum had come and gone in waves like a stubborn tide. Men had drawn closer than Tenorio liked and been pushed back not by any visible threat but by a feeling in their knees that told them the bones involved in standing were reconsidering their allegiances. Fires had been lit too near and then kicked out with bad language. Laws had been invented and argued. Tomas had sung again and then spoken a story about a fish who wanted to climb a tree and when he got to the part where the fish understood who he was and stopped trying to be anything else a woman cried and pretended it was because smoke had gotten in her eye.

Night made the bowl a shape the eye could not understand. It ate light around its edges. It gave back stars in the center as if something had polished them. The hum, when it came, vibrated the visible world less and climbed instead up into people’s skulls and announced that it could sit there if it wanted. Eryn stood with her hands in the pockets of her cut-down coat and watched the dark as if it were a chessboard full of pieces she had never seen before but was confident she could learn.

“This is going to call men to themselves,” she said to Sid, when they had contrived a corner of conversation at the margin of shadows. “Some will like who they are. Some will not. The ones who do not will get loud. The ones who do will get quiet and do the work. You need to find those before the other ones start naming the days.”

“I wish I had brought more people who know how to make soup for a crowd,” Sid said. He had cleaned three noses bled by humming and said the right thing twice and the wrong thing once and been forgiven in the way kings are forgiven when the one hearing them is tired. “Soup keeps men from philosophy.”

“Soup is philosophy,” she said. “It says we have heat and time and someone cared enough to stir. It says we are staying at least long enough to eat and that means the world hasn’t ended. Make soup in the yard if you want to stay king.”

“I will send for bags of split peas,” he said. “And salt that doesn’t taste like it comes with a sermon.”

“Don’t be good at this,” she said, and her mouth made a shape he had not seen yet, a warning that had something kind under it. “If you are good at this men will start bringing you their holes and ask you to hum for them.”

“I am tired of being good at anything,” he said, and it was not a king’s truth and because of that it felt like one I-beam in a building not yet decided on.

From the bowl came a breath unlike the others, a filling that changed the pitch of the night. The oak leaves froze without wind. A ring of dew showed in a place no dew had any business appearing, and then a line of light ran around the depression like a snake made of an old word that had just remembered itself. Every throat in the company clicked or tightened or swallowed or failed to, depending on its history. The curve they had seen earlier shifted and the dust showed a lattice where another curve lay under it in the opposite direction, and for a second the pattern lifted out of the earth in a way that made men remember why people had bothered inventing gods.

“Back,” Tenorio said, although no one had moved forward. “Back,” he repeated, and they obeyed the old man as men obey a tide table.

Sid felt something wanting in him go to its knees and apologize and change. He did not know what it had been wanting to start with. He also did not speak the word Eryn had forbidden him. He kept his mouth at being a human thing and not an altar. The light went out not like a candle but like breath deciding it was done. The hum went low and lower and then away, and the world slid back into its previous wrongness. Someone laughed too loud at nothing and then covered his mouth as if the laugh might draw attention. Someone else prayed in a language Sid did not know and had never heard inside city walls.

“Tomorrow,” Dolores said, which was such an act of faith that Sid had to turn his face away so she would not see what that word did to him. “We will set the tents here and here. We will send a boy with a back that can be trusted to the salt road. We will choose three words to say at market and not more. We will appoint two people to listen and say no. We will write a sign that uses simple nouns.”

“We will also go down at first light to the lower farms,” Ajit added, softer. “Because the men there will take advantage of the city’s eyes pointing uphill. We do not allow men to drink with both hands while they are being watched by God and dragons.”

He had said it. The word had been said in a way that was almost a joke and not a joke, and it hung for a breath in the night and then became part of it.

Eryn looked at Sid, and there was that small, awful, private happiness again that someone else’s mouth knew the same shape your mouth wanted. She touched his elbow, which was not a promise and not permission. “Do not say that in the hall,” she advised. “Save it for here when your mouth is of no consequence.”

“I usually save my worst words for the places where they will do me the least harm,” he said. “I am learning to do the opposite. It seems necessary to both survive and be worth surviving.”

“Look at you,” she said, amused and almost fond and furious with herself for both. “Trying to survive and matter at once. It will tire you past your marrow.”

They kept watch. They made a circle of bodies around the circle of ground. They took turns sleeping on their sides like simple animals. Sid lay with his ear pressed to the earth at one point because something in him wanted to hear the hum the way a child hears a mother through a wall. He heard nothing but the breathing of his men and the shift and creak of oaks and the small astonished noises horses make when they have dreamed. He thought about the year Eryn had asked for and whether that year would mean anything against the shape under the ground. He thought about soup. He thought about tying ribbons to water and learning new knots. He thought about his father saying you can make anything into something else if you hammer long enough and wondered if this would forgive being hammered.

Before dawn a thin layer of ash had fallen over the lip away from the wind, a thing that looked like snow in a story told by a liar and a mother who wanted to comfort her child. It made footprints sharp. It held a record of the way the raccoons had come, curious and rude, and then left offended in their raccoon way. Sid stood and took a breath and held it as if the day would start when he released. It did not. It started when Bee’s shadow fell long and she said, from beside him where her mouth was too simple to lie. “There are men on the lower road with salt armor,” she said. “And a flag with a clam drawn on it in a way that thinks clams are proud.”

“Coastal,” Dolores said with more punctuation than some essays.

“Too early,” Eryn said. “We have not decided our words and already they are delivering theirs. They will want to make a harbor out of your bowl. They will want to put their boats in it and call it a blessing even if the boats have no water to float on.” She fixed her scarfless throat with her hand as if to remind it that she still belonged to herself. “We should go be clever, then. It’s a day for it.”

Sid picked up his coat. His boots found their own feet. He felt the copper crown at home on the courthouse windowsill as if it were a small animal he had failed and would have to explain to later. He thought about soup again and about the shape under the earth and the taste of metal and the way Eryn had said his name and made it into something he nearly wanted to be. He squared his shoulders, which was ridiculous because shoulders are not squares, and smiled without showing teeth, which was a practice that had taken him a year to learn and had saved him three times.

“We will go see,” he said, and this time when he said it there was no one there who needed reminding that this was what he knew how to do. They went down toward the lower road as a small band, into the shadows made by things bigger than they were, and he felt the city behind him and the bowl at his back, and it was like walking away from a lit room that might burn and knowing you would come back no matter what the men with clams thought they could claim by arriving early.

They found the coastal men where the lower road swung through a stand of valley oaks that had learned to drink deep and not talk about it. You could smell the sea before you saw them. It was a scent that did not belong to this land: salt dried on skin so many times it became a second hide, tar and old rope and the faint licorice of fennel seeds men chew against nausea. Their armor was white at first glance, but it was not purity; it was salt, cured onto boiled leather until the plates clicked like teeth. The flag with the clam was more elaborate than the countryside deserved, painted in pearl pigment so the creature’s shell threw off little parings of light and its hinge had been shaded by someone who had loved a hinge too much. They had brought a cleric in a blue stole whose God preferred horizons and did not sit well in rooms. They had brought a chest you could smell the coins in even from horseback.

The leader, whether named that by his men or by himself, came forward with the tall man’s ease of one who sails more than walks and liked being taller than people who worked in dirt. He wore his hair plaited with strips of dried eel that had been worked to shine like leather, and his thumb bore a ring carved from a whalebone’s whorl. “Lord Sid of the Copper,” he said, the way you address a neighbor whose dog has started killing your chickens and you intend to be just. “We were told by the traveling kind—tinker, washer, a woman with a tattoo of a fish on her throat—that a phenomenon of interest has woken in your jurisdiction. Sea laws apply in cases of phenomena. We are obliged to offer assistance and, in return, maintain a share in the naming rights.”

“My jurisdiction prefers plows to phenomena,” Sid replied, pleasantly enough to be a danger. He did not give the man his title back. He did not say, I know your sort, gone inland to remind it there is a horizon it does not own. He did not say, you are late, because lateness was sometimes the only manner left to men who had everything else. “And the only naming rights that apply belong to the people whose teeth have been humming since yesterday. They would like to be asked before you put your clam on it.”

The coastal leader’s eyes did what eyes do when a man feels he has been spoken to as an equal by someone he thought needed his pronunciation, narrowing and then opening as if the sun had come out at an awkward time. “We don’t plant clams,” he said, affront making his vowels saltier. “We plant banners to warn men not to drown. We are here to prevent. You inlanders are fond of pretending things are not happening until they have met your fence. The sea does not offer fences. It offers advice. Listen, then. If what you have is a vent, we cinch it. If it’s a sink, we measure it, we chart it, we forbid washing clothes in it until we say you may. If it is a saint’s mouth, we build a chapel. We share tithe.”

Dolores rode a pace up and cut in with that particular thin politeness that makes men think of paper cuts. “If it’s a saint’s mouth,” she said, “you will donate shingles and we will ask the saint if she prefers a roof.” She looked the man’s armor up and down as if pricing it in her head. “If it is a vent, you dump enough salt on it to kill three fields, and you do not make it as far as the second tree before men who planted those fields cut your elk-leather to feed their children. If it’s a sink, there will be no charts until you learn that a map can scorch a land as efficiently as fire. We have rules already on the road up. You will follow them or you will dine with your clam under the bridge and your men can sing you to sleep.”

Eryn had hung back because she made a point of not being a member of anyone’s we unless she agreed to it out loud in the morning light. Now she slid forward until she was where the coastal men could fail to see her by thinking about anything else. Her scarf was gray as cloud on a day when the sea means something and knows you think it does. “You people,” she said, looking past them at the flag because sometimes you have to speak to a thing that believes it is a person, “build churches where something leaks and call it reverence. Then you sell blessing by the scoop. This is not your leak. You can stay if you can be quiet. I doubt you can. But surprise me. That’s a dare you will not resist.”

The cleric with the blue stole had the sort of face that becomes more itself when someone needs him to be reasonable. He stood with his hands folded so that the ring on his forefinger—the one with the tiny fish engraved on the band, chasing its tail—showed. “We can bless without owning,” he said, and you could tell he had practiced that sentence in different towns and been met with laughter or prayer according to weather. “We can stand at a distance and say no words. Sometimes the saying of no words is a blessing. We have an oath for that. It is very short.”

Tomas, who had been whittling nothing into the shape of something while leaning against a fencepost that did not need his company, dropped a curl of wood and smiled at the cleric in a way that said you might drink soup with me one day. “I know that oath,” he said. “It goes mmhmm. Can your men mmhmm with salt on their teeth.”
