Eryn walked the new line and looked at the way the cracks refused to be dramatic. She had tended to love only the dramatic because it had been a way of insisting she was alive when the quiet tried to convince her otherwise. Now she made friends with modest rupture. She knelt and pressed her fingers to the least interesting seam and felt there the whisper a bow makes before a string is drawn. She wanted to shout. She wanted to sing. She did not do either because the Dust Monks had taught her something against her will and Bee’s knots had taught her the same thing willingly. She stood and shaded her eyes and saw from the ridge the dust rise from the first bowl as if a man had thrown a blanket in anger and then shook it until he remembered blankets are for warmth. She thought, because she had not been gifted with patience the way some had been but had learned to steal it, that perhaps the bowls and the line wanted to be looms. She did not test the word aloud. She put it in her mouth like a seed.

Gavino came back at dusk with company who took up space by claiming not to. Eryn put her palms on her knees and asked them what their mothers would think if the last thing their sons did was argue with a woman about pigs on a day that had made patience an art. They bristled less at being made ridiculous than at being made ordinary. Tomas wandered up the path with a thread on his wrist and a bone in his pocket and told a long, wearying story about a man who lowered a pig into a well to see if it would come out clean and how the pig had fallen in love with the dark and refused to come back and how the man had been forced to climb down and live there and how the town had had to either bless the well or fill it and they had done neither because they’d become the sort of people who could not make a choice. It was a pointless story that was either about them or not and that annoyed them enough that they left just to spite it. Santi squeezed Tomas on the back of the neck in thanks and Tomas shrugged like a man who knows exactly what he has done.

Night broke open without theater. Under the fig-painted crenels, Sid read the day back to himself the way a man reads a recipe to see where he had lied. He and Dolores turned the tin in their hands and both thought of their mothers without saying the word, because tin remembers better than paper and both their mothers had been made to make do with it. He thought of the boy Pico asleep under a cart with one shoe half on, of Luz listening to flies decide where to land, of Lord Baeza dreaming of a wave with edges, of Sister Vero turning her mirror to face the wall, of Tenorio without his rings feeling and not liking his lightness, of Ajit with his rag around his neck snoring like a man who has earned every rasp. He thought of Eryn at the second bowl with the gray scarf tied not at her throat but round her arm and the mare’s breath close by and the black edge within reach if she allowed it and the thread in her pocket with her name on the stone.

He slept and did not dream in a way that felt like trust rather than exhaustion. The bowls hummed and then did not. The line sighed again, and two raccoons paused at the edge of it, offended, and then found another path because animals are atheists and it serves them. In the morning, when the sky decided to be a mint version of blue, Fresno woke still being Fresno instead of something else, and that counted as a victory that could not be marked on any ledger. Sid went to the rope before he went to the courthouse because he had made a law and it would be good to obey it in a visible way. He put one hand on Bee’s knot and one hand on the rope that Baeza’s men had tarred and he put his mouth close to the air over the bowl and he did not speak into it. He let it be. The hum came as if pleased.

He turned and saw Eryn below at the bend in the lower road where hawkweed grows without permission. She did not come up. She did not lift a hand. The gray scarf was around her wrist and looked, for a moment, like a ribbon Bee might have tied as a joke on the world. He went down the path until the rope asked him with its rub to stop and he did. She stood inside the little gate Marta had made like a removed piece of fence and looked, not at him, but at the slope. “I have a new word I am not ready to believe,” she said without greeting, because there are days you can only save your life by being unromantic. “I will say it when I can say it without thinking of men building churches out of it.”

“I will sit here,” Sid said, and did, in dust that had learned to be domestic. “I will tell no one your word. I will do the things I am good at doing that keep boys’ hands from empty places. I will make soup laws and breath laws and rope oaths and I will write your not-word into the part of me that makes decisions and I will obey it without speaking it.”

“Do that,” she said. “Do your little magic and I will do mine. The world likes little magics better than big ones because little magics happen while the world is looking the other way.” She almost smiled, and then the almost did the work of a whole smile simply because it had to. “When you make a bed for men to go to when they would otherwise light a fire, make it far enough from the rope that the hum has to work to reach them. Give them something to do with their hands that is not their knives. Give them the bones of goats and string and tell them to make saints out of them. They’ll laugh at you and then they’ll start and then they’ll keep going because they have found a thing that won’t make their friends bleed.”

“Will you come into the city,” he asked, and it was a stupid question and it was the right one because he wanted to know if his city deserved her. He wanted to know if his people could sit at a table and not try to make her name theirs.

“Not today,” she said. “There’s a boy from Piedra who thinks he can teach the hum his song. I need to sit with him and tell him he is right and then show him which part of right is safe. Also there is a man who will come with a cart and try to sell the black in the second bowl by the ounce as if it were medicine. I mean to remove his wheels. It will profit him to learn to carry what he sells.”

When he stood to go, because the rope was a beast and had pulled enough on both of them to make retreat the honorable act, he said the only one of his private sentences he would dare aloud. “When the word comes,” he told her, and his mouth made it gentle, “I will say it wrong first. That is my habit. Correct me.”

She nodded, and for a moment he saw her as a seamstress and not as a cutter of threads, as a woman who could stand at a loom and call men to bring her what they had and make from it a pattern no one had believed could be worn. Then she turned her face back to the slope and the hum, and he went up to the rope and down to the city and into the day that had already decided to be difficult without having the dignity of being dramatic.

By noon the city had learned three new ways to keep from breaking. Ajit hung buckets of water at corners that had never seen kindness and told whoever walked by that it was theirs. Sister Vero set her mirror where it would catch only the hands and not the bowl, and men came to see their hands and to discover that they did not mind them as much as they had the day before. Luz taught two women how to make the dust move on the drumskin and those women taught four and one of them named the pattern she made for a horse that had died and somehow the naming made the pattern less sad. Lord Baeza took his armor apart the rest of the way and sat in his shirt in the heat and let a child tie a ribbon around his wrist and did not remove it. Tenorio took his rings back when the shimmer failed to rise at the expected hour and put them on one by one like promises and sighed as if vows could be a relief.

In the evening the rope held a man in place who would have run to the bowl to shout a secret; he held him like a friend might hold a shirt. The man cried not because the rope denied him but because he realized he had not been listening for most of his life and that the feeling under his ribs was not one he could sell. He sat and Tomas sat with him and told him a story about a fish who had learned to climb and then had learned that the best thing about climbing was descending without shame. The story had no moral and therefore it could be kept.

On the fifth morning, which no one had pinned hopes on and therefore it permitted a little grace, the black edge in the second bowl lifted two fingers’ thickness and held without thinking better of itself. Eryn did not say her word. Sid did not go north. Ajit taught a boy to pull a chain with the right muscle. Dolores tied a knot as if the past were a thing you could make a belt from that did not rub. Lord Baeza watched a man who had decided to be better without saying it and thought, privately, that the horizon might exist even inland. Tenorio put Luz’s drumskin to his ear and hummed a note that made the dust lay in an old pattern he remembered from a quarry that had become a lake, and he cried because a man is allowed and then went on with his day. Sister Vero sat with her mirror in her lap and did not try to explain anyone to anyone.

Gavino did not come with his pigs. He sent a boy whose ear did not yet bleed. The boy left a note tied in bad twine to Marta’s brush gate that said an apology without the word and carried in it the ignorance of how to begin. Marta tucked the note into the tin and told Dolores there were worse beginnings. Sid wrote on the slate the breath schedule for the day and Ajit wrote beneath it a rude aside that made two men grin and do the work and that saved three minutes and three minutes add up over a season. Bee tied a ribbon no one saw to a place where only a woman who had loved someone slippery would look, and later that afternoon Eryn found it and laughed out loud like a girl.

When the sun laid down flat on the ridge and the bowls sang each to each in the shy talk of instruments who were just learning, the city hummed back. It was not a hymn. It was not a pledge. It was not even music as much as a refusal to be silent where silence would be taken as consent. The mourning ring received three promises and one regret. The rope held. The soup learned a new ratio of onion to salt. Men took off their rings before they got to the rope without being told. The tin held the paper through a brief wind that wanted to make men watch it rather than work and failed. And in the night, in the place where he had learned to put his want where the moon could judge it without shaming him, Sid slept with his hand open and Eryn slept with her hand in the dirt and the hum did not press harder than either could bear. It was not victory. It was what you need to keep going long enough to make victory a word you can say without the taste of blood.
